Optimizing preparations of Co Fischer-Tropsch catalysts for stability against sintering Calvin H. Bartholomew * Mahmood Rahmati Marcus A. Reynolds Department of Chemical Engineering, Brigham Young University, Provo, UT, 84602, United States Department of Chemical Engineering Brigham Young University Provo UT 84602 United States ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Catalyst deactivation is of a major concern in industrial applications. Catalyst deactivation in any process can be minimized through: (i) appropriate catalyst design, and (ii) careful process control. In the present review we focus on the design of a Co catalyst to significantly hinder catalyst deactivation via sintering during FT reaction while enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity. First, it is shown how support and promoter physical and chemical properties can affect Co catalyst design. Support physical and chemical properties essential for preparing an optimally active, selective, and stable, commercial Co FT catalysts are recommended. Secondly, it is explained how carefully-controlled deposition of a Co salt via industrially-realistic methods is critical in controlling catalyst precursor-support interactions, nanocrystal size, and spatial distributions vital to sintering resistance. Three catalyst precursor deposition methods are discussed: impregnation, precipitation, and solution combustion; advantages and disadvantages of each method are detailed. Finally, effects of drying, calcination, and reduction on catalyst properties important to activity, selectivity and resistance to sintering are explained, and best practices for conducting each step are recommended. Keywords FT catalyst Support Drying Calcination Reduction Sintering 1 Introduction Catalyst preparation was for many decades, i.e., from 1900 to 1960, largely an art; discovery of improved catalysts was made using empirical methods. However, since 1960, catalytic science and engineering have contributed to the understanding, design, and preparation of catalysts [1]. International symposiums on the scientific basis for the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts have been held quadrennially in Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium since 1976. Hutchings and Vedrine [2] reviewed many preparation methods used commercially for several different catalyst types (e.g., supported, unsupported, oxides, acid catalysts, etc.) and provided empirical observations described as “carefully guarded know-how in the catalyst industry.” Bartholomew and Farrauto [1] address important methods of catalyst preparation and basic insights into surface and liquid phase chemistries and examples thereof for a number of important catalytic processes including Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS). Two highly-useful, complementary books on catalyst preparation edited by Regalbuto [3] and by de Jong, [4] contain chapter reviews that focus in detail on different aspects of the chemistry and physics of important preparation methods, including examples of scientific studies of the critical steps in preparation and pretreatment of supported metals. Reviews by van de Loosdrecht et al. [5] and Munnik et al. [6] address some aspects of recent developments in preparation of supported catalysts, including studies of specific aspects of supports and promoters for supported Co catalysts during FTS. The principal objectives of catalyst design and preparation are high activity, selectivity for the desired product, and activity/mechanical stability. In the design of commercial catalysts, compromises in activity and selectivity are typically made in the interest of high stability [1]. Catalyst stability is typically addressed under the topic of catalyst deactivation. Catalyst deactivation is a major concern for industrial catalytic applications [7,8]. Catalyst deactivation rate and its extent depends on two principal factors: (i) catalyst design and properties and (ii) reaction conditions [9]. Both these factors should be optimized to maintain the highest catalyst performance (i.e., activity and selectivity) with the time on stream. For effective prevention of catalyst deactivation, it is necessary to understand underlying processes of decay. Deactivation mechanisms for Co catalyst during FT reaction include: (i) carbon deposition and carbide formation; (ii) sintering; (iii) poisoning; (iv) oxidation; (v) surface reconstruction; and (vi) Co-support compound formation [10,11]. Deactivation by poisoning in FTS can be overcome by effective removal of poisons such as sulfur compounds [12], hydrogen chloride [13,14], and nitrogen compounds [1,8] from the syngas entering the catalyst bed. Deactivation by oxidation and Co-support compound formation during commercial FT reaction can be prevented by preparing a Co catalyst with a nanocrystal size larger than about 6 nm and by maintaining a CO conversion below 70–75 % to maintain a sufficiently low PH2O [15,16]. Surface reconstruction of Co and deactivation by carbon during FT reaction are apparently inevitable but can be moderated by lowering PCO and maintaining a H2/CO ratio of 2.1 [17,18]. Sintering, the loss in Co active surface area due to crystallite growth, can be a significant cause of activity loss in Co FT catalysts [19]. For example, deactivation of a Pt promoted Co/γ−Al2O3 Co catalyst by sintering over the course of about 54 days on stream was estimated to be about 25 % of the total deactivation [20]. Despite this significant contribution to total deactivation, it has been shown experimentally that catalyst deactivation by sintering during commercial FT reaction can be minimized through appropriate catalyst design [17,19]. Our companion, comprehensive review [19] addresses mechanisms, sintering rates, and loss of activity due to sintering of supported metals. Details of Co catalyst design and preparation to produce a sintering-resistant FT catalyst are the focus of this current review. Properties of catalysts which affect sintering resistance are highly reliant on choices of support, promoters, and precise catalyst synthesis methods, including choices of metal precursor, method of precursor deposition on the support, solvent, solvent additives, and methods of drying, calcination, and reduction. Catalyst properties that affect sintering rate include average nanocrystal (NC) size, NC size distribution, average pore size, pore size distribution, support surface chemistry such as metal-support bonding (adhesion energy i.e., the work required to separate a NC from the support) [21], and NC spatial distribution. General sintering mechanisms affecting supported metals include (i) atomic migration or Ostwald Ripening (OR) and (ii) crystallite migration and coalescence (CMC) [19]. For preparation of a catalyst resistant to sintering, it is important to understand effects of changes in catalyst preparation and their resultant properties on sintering mechanisms. In this paper we review in detail effects of: (i) support and promoter properties; (ii) methods of adding the active precursor to the support with associated chemistries; and (iii) pretreatment conditions and chemistries, i.e., drying, calcination and reduction, on sintering resistance of Co FT catalysts. The catalyst design principles in this review have broad application to other supported catalyst systems. 1.1 How support and promoter properties affect sintering behavior of Co catalysts Supports and promoters play an important role in increasing or decreasing initial Co NC size and altering catalyst stability [1,22–30]. Support chemical and physical properties control in part (i) support-metal bonding, i.e., adhesion energy [19], and (ii) NC size, size distribution, and NCs spatial distribution and therewith sintering rate. Control of chemical and physical properties is analogous to two knobs used to optimize the overall support properties. One knob controls support physical characteristics such as support surface area, average pore diameter and pore size distribution, while the second knob controls support bulk and surface chemical properties. It will be shown that support additives, including oxide stabilizers and basic oxides, can substantially affect both chemical and physical properties of a support. Important support physical properties affecting sintering rate include surface area, pore volume, porosity, average pore size, and pore size distribution [19]. The following are examples of how these support properties influence sintering resistance and activity selectivity performance of Co FT catalysts: [19] (i) Moderately-high SA (50−150 m2/g) oxide supports containing pores of 10−20 nm in diameter contribute to formation of Co NCs of 11−14 nm in diameter, which maximize C5+ selectivity while minimizing sintering [31,32]. (ii) Moderately low pore volume (0.5−0.6 cm3/g) and porosity (< 0.5) are necessary to ensure high support mechanical stability [1,5] against catalyst particle fracture, crushing, and attrition, which can otherwise cause process failures in both fixed bed and slurry bubble column reactors. Pertinent support chemical properties include molecular chemical structure, composition, purity (including less than 25 ppm of Na [33]), OH adsorption capacity, hydrothermal stability, tendency to form Co support compounds, and adhesion energy of Co NCs to the support; these properties can in turn affect Co reducibility, Co NC size, spatial distribution, and resistance to sintering via CMC [19]. For example: (i) Moderately-strong adhesion energy is an important factor in controlling spatial distribution and NC size [22]. If adhesion energy is too large, reduction of cobalt to Co0 occurs only at high temperatures [34] (i.e., T > 450 °C) at which undesirably large NCs are formed; however, a weak interaction enables high crystallite mobility during reduction, resulting in an undesirably low dispersion, nonuniform NC size and spatial distributions, and a propensity for sintering to large NCs. Since Al2O3 supports interact with Co more strongly than SiO2 supports [5,23], Co/Al2O3 catalysts are more stable against sintering than Co/SiO2 catalysts of similar physical properties and prepared under similar conditions. (ii) Addition of 1−10 % of a stabilizer consisting of an oxide of Al, Ba, Ce, La, Mn, Si, Ti, or Zr to Al2O3, SiO2, or TiO2 supports minimizes undesirable Co-support compound formation. (iii) Addition of a reduction promoter such as Pt, Ru, or Re in concentrations of 0.03−0.05, 0.1, or 0.3−0.5 %, respectively facilitate reduction to Co0 [35–38]. A typical commercial Co catalyst consists of 20−30 wt% cobalt and 0.05–1.0 % of a noble metal reduction promoter supported on Al2O3, SiO2, or TiO2 stabilized with one of the oxide additives listed in (ii) above [19]. Carbon supports are not used commercially because of: (i) generally low adhesion energy (Eadh) between Co NCs and the support that results in a high extent of sintering; and (ii) deposition or migration of Co NCs outside the pores of the carbon support [36]. Examples of Co commercial catalysts, including support and promoter choice by company, are listed in Table 1 . A number of companies have also patented other Co catalyst supports and promoters. Why are 20−30 % Co and an average NC diameter of about 10−12 nm desirable for commercial FT catalysts? Namely, because for this range of properties, the mass-based activity, C5+ selectivity, and productivity are optimally high [37,38]. It follows logically that a catalyst prepared by strong monolayer adsorption, containing 4−5 wt% Co of relatively small NCs (e.g., 4−6 nm) or even a catalyst containing 10 % or less Co is not commercially-relevant in terms of its its activity, selectivity, and productivity, although this catalyst is likely more resistant to sintering via OR and CMC. Thus, the subsequent discussion of effects of support and catalyst preparation methods will focus primarily on Co catalysts having loadings of 15−40 wt%. In design of Co catalysts for fixed-bed reactors, pore-diffusional and heat transport limitations must be avoided [1,19]. A sufficiently small catalyst extrudate size and shape geometry with an effective particle diffusional length less than about 200−225 μm is required [36], since at higher diffusional lengths, C5+ selectivity and mass-based catalyst activity decrease and CH4 selectivity increases substantially [36]. The smallest practical extrudate diameter range is about 0.8–1.0 mm; to meet an effective particle diffusional length at this diameter, a trilobe extrude is required (see Fig. 1 ). For a trilobe extrudate [43] (Fig. 1a) of the same diameters, the lobes enable the diffusional length range to be decreased to 220−275 μm. If an eggshell deposit of d/4 is created, the diffusion length for a 1.0 mm diameter trilobe is reduced to 138 μm (Fig. 1b). An eggshell deposit can be formed by spraying, impregnation of a viscous solution or molten salt, or drying at high rates. However, since an eggshell deposit contains an especially high concentration of Co, the sintering rate via CMC will be higher due to the smaller distance between NCs. Soled et al. [44] established how matching support and Co precursor and/or adding an oxide stabilizer can be used to control Co reducibility, dispersion, and metal-support interactions. For example, addition of silicon to the TiO2 lattice stabilizes the support surface area and retards formation of cobalt titanates, while surface treatment of TiO2 with ZrO2 inhibits formation of TiOx species during reduction, which would otherwise block surface cobalt sites. In the preparation of Co/Al2O3 by impregnation, formation of clusters of Co NCs is highly undersirable, since it greatly facilitates sintering by CMC [45–47]. Sasol researchers [47] found that coating of the Al2O3 support surface with 7% carbon (C), followed by impregnation of the support with Co in two steps (Fig. 2 ) produces a spatially uniform distribution and increased activity by 60 % compared to a catalyst prepared without a carbon pre-coating. Cheng et al. [45] investigated the effects of carbon pre-coating of the support with a glucose solution to achieve various concentrations of carbon (5, 10, 50 wt%) on the properties and performance of Co/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 3 shows the catalyst structure evolution during preparation by the carbon pretreatment method, from initial impregnation to the end of the air calcination step. Since calcination in N2 is not effective in removing carbon from the Co oxide surface, calcination in air is a necessary step in preparation of supported Co catalysts by carbon-precoating. Otherwise, carbon layers remaining on the Co oxide surface will lower FT activity. While high temperature air calcination is necessary, it does result in a slight increase in Co oxide NC size. Nevertheless, a Co/SiO2 catalyst prepared by support carbon-precoating with 10 wt% carbon has a smaller Co3O4 NC size (8.5 nm compared to 15.5 nm for the untreated catalyst, as determined by H2 uptake). Most importantly, this treatment ensures a uniform spatial distribution of Co crystallites, thereby lowering the sintering rate. Jiang et al. [46] coated a SiO2 support with various amounts of amorphous carbon by carburization in an inert gas of glucose added to the support via impregnation. The authors suggested that carbon precoating of the support decreases Co NC size and increases the extent of reduction (EOR). Cheng et al. [45] found large Co agglomerates formed in the preparation of Co/SiO2 without a carbon coating, while with the carbon coating small, uniformly-spaced NCs of approximately the same size were observed. While this section of our review focuses on effects of support properties on sintering of supported Co NCs via CMC, there are also important interesting noble metal/support catalytic systems in which OR is primary mechanism for sintering, which in the interest of the broader picture are briefly addressed here. Sintering via OR in these catalytic systems can be mitigated through ingenious modifications of the support. Sintering via OR has two rate limiting steps: (1) formation of metal adatoms and (2) diffusion of metal adatoms on the support. Either blocking adatom formation or mitigating adatom diffusion over a critical distance on the support can prevent Ostwald Ripening. The rate of adatom formation for a supported NC depends on the NC chemical potential that is a function of both surface energy and adhesion energy [48,49]. NCs with lower surface energy (SE) and higher adhesion energy are less susceptible to sintering via Ostwald Ripeninig. Addition of a small amount of a second metal to the active NC phase can decrease NC SE; addition of a strongly interacting oxide with oxygen defects to the support can greatly increase adhesion energy between NCs and the support [49]. In either case, sintering by OR is prevented via blocking of adatom formation [49–53]. On the other hand, homogeneous addition of functional groups to the support can be used as a method to trap adatoms and thus mitigate the diffusion of adatoms or small NCs over the support [54–60]. Jones et al. [55] successfully used polyhedral ceria to produce anchoring sites on alumina oxide support for trapping Pt adatoms formed during a diesel oxidation reaction. A similar anchoring effect was observed via addition of CoOx to a SiO2 supported Au catalyst [61]. Hydroxyl groups and acid sites can also be used as anchoring sites [62,63]. van den Berg et al. [57] showed that functionalizing an SiO2 support with aminopropyl groups retards sintering by OR of Cu NCs during the methanol synthesis by hindering the diffusion of adatoms over the support surface. Finally, sintering can be hindered by altering the number of acid sites on the support via addition of other elements to the support. For example, McVicker et al. [62] showed that addition of a low to moderate concentration of BaO to alumina reduces sintering of well-dispersed Ir NCs supported on alumina by neutralizing acid sites. 2 Impact of precursor deposition methods on catalyst properties related to sintering Each preparation step (precursor deposition, drying, calcination, and reduction) significantly impacts physical and chemical properties of a catalyst. In section 2, strategies for controlling how precursor deposition methods influence physical and chemical properties of Co FT catalysts, which in turn affect sintering rates, will be discussed. In section 3, effects of pretreatment methods (drying, calcination, and reduction) will be addressed. Since fresh, commercially relevant Co catalysts contain NCs of about 8−12 nm and OR occurs only for Co NCs smaller than 8 nm in diameter [19], the focus in following sections is on preparation methods which avoid sintering via CMC while optimizing activity and selectivity. Precursor deposition methods play an especially critical role in facilitating preparation of Co catalysts having the desired physical and chemical properties discussed in the introduction. Effective commercially-relevant precursor deposition methods which facilitate obtaining these properties are presently limited to (i) dry or wet impregnations [2–6], (ii) deposition-precipitation [64–66], and (iii) solution combustion of Co precursors [67–70]. Other presently-available methods are generally not advised. For example, strong adsorption of Co metal precursors on alumina supports is not workable due to the high pH required, which would cause precipitation of Co(OH)2 and formation of very stable, surface Co aluminates. Moreover, metal loadings during strong adsorption are generally limited to 1−5 wt% [62]. 2.1 Impregnation of support with precursor solution Impregnation is the simplest and most common procedure for dispersing a metal precursor in the pores of a catalyst support. Two kinds of impregnation were mentioned previously: (i) dry or incipient wetness impregnation and (ii) wet or slurry impregnation. In dry impregnation (DI), a precise volume of precursor solution is added, usually dropwise, to a dry support to fill the pores; in wet impregnation (WI), catalyst particles are immersed in a large excess of precursor solution, which is stirred while liquid is slowly removed by a partial vaccum. For both kinds of impregnation, it may be necessary to prevent uneven filling of pores with precursor-solution due to air pockets inside large pores; a preferred method is to evacuate the catalyst before addition of the precursor solution using a well-designed vacuum, liquid handling system [71,72]. During both kinds of impregnation, pores are filled with a metal precursor solution based on capillary forces up to several hundred atmospheres. Diffusion of the impregnation solution into the support pores follows the Young-Laplace equation (Eq. (1)). (1) Δ p = 2 γ l v r p c o s θ where Δ p is the capillary pressure of a pore and the driving force for intrusion of the liquid into the pore, γ l v is the surface tension at the liquid-vapor interface, θ is the contact angle, and r p is the pore radius. Increasing γ l v which is a positive linear function of viscosity of the impregnating liquid, facilitates better infiltration of the impregnating solution into the pores, which can contribute to improved metal dispersion, improved NC size distribution, and uniform spatial distribution in a fully-prepared Co FT catalyst. Capillary pressure is inversely proportional to pore radius and is thus highest for micropores. Capillary pressure for micropores and small mesopores is typically large enough to force air from the pores. However, the capillary pressure of large macropores in a support, such as alpha-Al2O3, may be too small to enable the displacement of entrained air. If θ < 90°, wetting of the support and penetration of the pores occur spontaneously with aqueous solution impregnations of most oxidic supports. If θ > 90°, the capillary pressure is negative, and an external force is required to force the liquid into the pores; this situation is likely for aqueous impregnations of hydrophobic supports, such as carbon [6]. Non aqueous solutions with non-polar liquids, such as ethanol or acetone, are more likely to spontaneously fill the pores of carbon supports. Advantages of impregnation include: its relative simplicity, rapidity, capability for depositing the precursor at moderately-high loadings (e.g., 10 wt% for a Co nitrate impregnation in the mesopores of an oxidic support), and the high likelihood of distributing the impregnating liquid with solution phase Co2+ uniformly along pores and through the catalyst particle. Another advantage is that following drying and calcination, cobalt is predominantly present as Co3O4 NCs, which have a moderate interaction with the support and thus are readily reduced to Co0 NCs in H2 at about 300−450 °C (lower temperatures for noble metal-promoted Co and higher temperatures without noble metals; higher reduction temperatures produce larger (8−12 nm) NCs). Disadvantages of impregnation are (i) the tendency for capillary flow of the impregnating liquid from inside pores to the exterior particle surface for Co nitrates at high drying rates, leading to an eggshell deposit of the cobalt precursor with relatively poor dispersion of the catalyst and a greater tendency to sinter; (ii) Co nitrate, used in most Co catalyst impregnations, once dissolved in water, creates an acidic solution which can cause dissolution of alumina, presumably in the form of dispersed aluminum hydroxides; and (iii) the necessity of repeating the impregnation, drying, and calcination to achieve higher Co loadings, e.g., for Co nitrate solution impregnation, 2−3 cycles are required to obtain a Co loading of 20−30 wt%. The first disadvantage may be overcome by introduction of viscosity enhancing agents [72] and carefully controlling drying rate (see Section 3.1). The second may be overcome by (i) increasing the pH slightly while avoiding precipitation of the Co2+ precursor; or (ii) stabilizing the alumina support through addition of basic oxides such as BaO or La2O3 before impregnation with Co nitrate solution. Overcoming the third disadvantage depends upon the amount of cobalt precursor that can be added for each impregnation, which depends upon on support pore volume and the specific volume of the precursor. From Table 2 , for Co(NO3)2·6H2O a pore volume of 0.79 mL/gsupp is required for a loading of 30 gCo/100 gsupp. For a typical Al2O3 support with a pore volume of 0.5 mL/gsupp, impregnation at room temperature with a concentrated solution of hydrated Co nitrate (solubility limit of 103 g/100 mLwater at 25 °C) containing 1.03 ghydrate /mLsoln or 0.20 gCo/mLsoln, the fraction of Co in the support = 0.20 gCo/mLsoln * 0.5 mLpore/gsupp = 0.10 gCo/gsupp, and thus the cobalt metal loading is 9.1 wt%. If an “optimal” Co metal loading of 23–35 % wt% is desired, three impregnations of a nitrate solution at room temperature will be necessary. After each impregnation, the catalyst must be dried and calcined. If, however, wet impregnation is carried out in a roto-evaporator or similar system at elevated temperatures (e.g., 70−90 °C), it is possible to obtain a 23−25 wt% Co catalyst with only two impregnations. As shown in Table 2, after the final calcination, Co3O4 will occupy only 6.7 mL per 100 g of support or 0.067 mL/gsupp. At first glance, a two-fold increase in metal loading might be attractive with corresponding doubling of the FT mass-based rate. However, previous experience teaches that metal dispersion decreases with increasing metal loading [1,73]; thus, the FT reaction mass-based rate will be less than a factor of two higher. Moreover, to attain higher loadings more impregnation steps would be required; at higher loadings, NC spacing decreases and the extent of sintering via CMC increases, unless other measures are taken, such as increasing Co-support interactions (increasing Eadh). One issue regarding preparation by impregnation is the time requirement for reaching homogeneity of the cobalt concentration throughout the support [5]. According to Geus [74], the uptake for dry impregnation (DI or impregnation to incipient wetness) is rapid due to large convective forces; Munnik et al. [6] cited evidence that the filling of pores via DI is complete and largely homogeneous. Other evidence suggests that immediately following DI, cobalt distribution through the support pores and single particles is non homogeneous [5]. Since during DI, solution is fed dropwise to a bed of particles while particles are mechanically mixed, cobalt concentration and degree of pore filling can vary among catalyst particles and throughout a single particle; moreover, while pores are mostly filled during DI to the point of incipient wetness, the solution does not fill void spaces continuously between particles. Thus, after DI, no mechanism exists by which differences in precursor concentrations between particles or groups of particles can be eliminated by interparticle diffusion, although sufficient intraparticle diffusion time could equalize concentration within each single particle. In the case of wet impregnation (WI or slurry impregnation), each particle communicates with the liquid surrounding all of the particles; thus, it is possible to equalize concentration differences in the entire sample by convective and diffusional forces. According to van de Loosdrecht et al. [5] the timeframe after wet impregnation for realizing a homogeneous cobalt precursor distribution throughout support particles during WI depends on pore geometry (pore diameter and length), viscosity of the solution, interaction between solution and support surface (i.e., contact angle and surface energies), and diffusion coefficients. This time frame is probably on the order of hours; Geus [74] determined that reaching homogeneity can take up to about 10 h. In Fig. 4 distributions of single Co3O4 particles obtained from SEM/EDS line scans after either DI or WI (the latter following 3 h of diffusion) and fast drying are shown [5,75,76]. Highly variable line scans are evident in Fig. 4a following DI and immediate rapid drying of the cobalt nitrate solution; if several hours of diffusion time had been allowed before drying, the line scans could have evened out to some extent. Fig. 4b shows substantially greater linearity in line scans of single catalyst particles with WI after diffusion over a 3 h period of Co salt solution and fast drying Thus, Fig. 4b indicates that after 3 h of diffusion following WI, largely homogeneous impregnation of Co3O4 is realized. Unfortunately, the foundation here for comparing DI and WI methods is less than perfect due to fast drying and not allowing diffusion time following DI. It is generally recommended that after either dry or wet impregnation methods that 3–10 h of diffusion time be allowed for each batch of catalyst before drying and calcination; moreover, a precise, less rapid drying method is necessary to facilitate 3D spatial uniformity in each catalyst particle and in a catalyst bed (see section 3.1). The chemistry of Co impregnation varies considerably with metal precursor, pH, and support surface chemistry. If these variables are not precisely chosen and controlled, formation of irreducible surface Co-support compounds can occur. According to Che [77] and van Steen et al. [78] understanding of the formation of surface spinels has progressed such that it can be visualized in the context of interfacial coordination chemistry. The chemistry of impregnation of SiO2 with Co nitrate and formation of surface Co silicate intermediates, while complex, has been well-studied [77–84]. Coulter and Sault [84] conducted a surface-science study of Co nitrate-impregnated silica, finding that vacuum drying of the catalyst prior to calcining produces a highly-stable silicate, while if the same sample were dried in air at 110 °C and calcined at 400 °C, highly reducible 8−10 nm NCs of Co3O4 are formed. In a study of factors affecting reducibility of Co/SiO2 prepared by impregnation, van Steen et al. [78] found that formation of surface Co silicates is minimized by (i) moderately-low support area (i.e., SA < 300 m2/g); (ii) Co precursors favoring a pH below 5 (e.g., nitrate as opposed to acetate) since above a pH of 5, larger quantities of irreducible silicates are formed; (iii) solvents of high polarity (e.g., water, as opposed to n-butanol) since low polarity favors interaction of silanol groups and the Co aquo-complex; (iv) drying at 120–150 °C, rather than 60–90 °C over 10–24 h vs. 1–4 h; and (v) calcining at 200–300 °C. Surface silanol groups, shown schematically in Fig. 5 play an important role in the formation of Co silicates; their concentrations are highly pH dependent. While pores are being filled with Co nitrate the pH can increase to about 4.5, at which condition the SiO2 surface contains a surplus of negative charge in the form of SiO− species, that promotes formation of hydrosilicates and silicates [78]. Mechanistic steps leading progressively to formation of Co hydrosilicates and silicates during impregnation of silica with a Co nitrate solution [77,78] are depicted in Fig. 5. The order is: (i) adsorption of water-bound Co2+ ions to SO− support surface species, (ii) dissociation of one water molecule associated with Co2+– SO− ions causes formation of CoSiO(OH) hydrosilicates (precursors to silicates), (iii) two hydrosilicates can bridge to form surface Co2Si2O3 and CoSiO2 silicates which are reducible only above about 700 °C, and (iv) decomposition of the hydrosilicate during drying and calcination could yield Co(OH)2, which can decompose to CoO and Co3O4. Although reduction of Co-silicates is difficult, their presence during catalyst preparation in small amounts may be necessary to act as anchoring sites, resulting in enhanced dispersion [84] and a moderately large Eadh. This hypothesis is also supported by previous work on Ni/SiO2 supported catalysts where Ni-silicate species assist in increasing catalyst dispersion [85]. Addition of organic additives, such as chelating agents and glycols, to the impregnation solution has been successfully used as method for modifying NC-precursor-support-surface interactions [51,86–94]. Chelating agents with higher affinity to react with Co2+, if calcined at high enough temperatures, can decrease the Co NC size [86] to optimal levels (i.e., 10−12 nm). However, adding chelating agents to adjust the Co NC size has the following two disadvantages: (i) The solubility of the Co precursor is decreased and thus, Co loading at each impregnation step may have to be lowered [90]. To overcome this challenge, the support can initially be treated with chelating agent followed by drying. In the subsequent impregnation step, the Co salt concentration can be increased, leading to higher loadings of Co2+ [90]. (ii) Chelating agents can increase the impregnation solution pH, which in turn can increase Co-support interactions and lead to formation of small CoO NCs that are difficult to reduce [88]. Koizumi et al. [91] studied the effects of glycol addition to the Co nitrate impregnation solution during preparation of a Co/SiO2 catalyst. They found that glycol addition to the impregnation solution, quantified by the ratio of moles of carbon to moles of cobalt (C/Co2+) in solution, is the crucial factor in determining the Co3O4 NC size after impregnation (see Fig. 6 ). High extents of Co reduction (more than 95 %) are realized in catalysts prepared using glycol addition due to formation of Co3O4 NCs during calcination that are subsequently more easily reduced (probably due to the presence of carbon on the SiO2 support). 2.2 Precursor deposition in support pores via deposition precipitation Deposition-precipitation (DP) is a specific method of precipitation, the objective of which is to precipitate the catalyst precursor in the form of a hydroxide or carbonate in the pores of a support by slowly adjusting the pH of a metal salt solution-support slurry through dropwise addition of a base such as NH4OH or (NH4)2CO3 while rapidly mixing the solution. Base and metal salt are carefully chosen to avoid the presence of species in the final catalyst that might later function as poisons, such as Na+ and SO4 2–. DP preparations show considerable promise for one-step deposition of the active precursor on the support. Some catalysts prepared by this method in the examples below have commercially relevant properties, although DP preparations of Co FT catalysts have yet to be commercialized. In DP, deposition in the pores is the first requirement, while precipitation in the bulk solution or on the exterior catalyst particle surface must be avoided. Since precipitation in solutions is likely to occur in the vicinity of the alkaline drops entering the solution, rapid mixing and sometimes cooling, which lowers nucleation/precipitation rates, are generally effective in minimizing this problem. The key to successful DP is the gradual addition of the precipitating agent (base) to avoid a local rise of Co precursor concentration above supersaturation, which could cause nucleation and precipitation in the liquid [65]. A significant disadvantage of DP can occur if NH3 is used as base, namely significant quantities of precipitated Co hydroxide species can adsorb strongly to the support surface to form surface and bulk Co hydrosilicates or Co aluminate, which are reduced to the metal only under high temperature conditions and which constitutes a loss of the active phase [37]. In consequence, the extent of Co reduced to metal NCs during typical reduction conditions can be significantly or substantially lower than for catalysts prepared by impregnation; the lower extent of reduction can lower intrinsic catalyst activity and C5+ selectivity, although two methods presented below appear to have minimized these problems. The advantages of catalyst preparation by DP include (i) a favorable, one-step route to achieving moderately-high to high loadings, i.e., 20–50 wt %, at higher or comparable dispersions compared to impregnation; (ii) when properly conducted, it favors uniform distribution of the active precursor inside support pores in a well-dispersed phase, a good fraction of which is moderately strongly held to the support surface; and (iii) Co NCs are less mobile because of their moderate to high Eadh and the significant presence of surface Co-support compounds, e.g., surface CoAl2O4, which serve to block, trap, or otherwise hinder surface diffusion of atoms or NCs. Thus, Co catalysts prepared by deposition precipitation are expected to have relatively high thermal and chemical stability towards sintering via either OR or CMC. Rahmati et al. [35] used both a simple, novel one-step preparation method, called solvent deficient precipitation (SDP), developed by Cosmas, Inc. [66], and DI to prepare Ag-promoted Co/Al2O3 catalysts. The SDP method involves mechanical stirring of Co nitrate with associated waters of hydration and (NH4)2CO3 with the support and a small quantity of water, clearly deficient for either wet or dry impregnation, but enough to form a slurry. Reducible oxides of Co are precipitated in the pores of the support, while the NH4NO3 by-product is easily separated. Co dispersion, EOR, and spatial distribution were found to be comparable for the two methods (see Table 3 ). Given the simplicity of the one pot SDP method, it is highly promising for catalyst preparation at small or large scale. However, the method must be further designed to lower CH4 selectivities. Lok [64] described a controlled-pH precipitation of a Co ammine in which Co oxide deposition is effected by ammonia evaporation and facilitated by matching the precursor charge with the oppositely charged support; this relatively new method enables 1-step preparation of Co/Al2O3 catalysts of 20−50 wt% Co loading, 30–40 m2/g of cobalt area (compared to about 12–20 m2/g for typical cobalt catalysts of 20 wt% loading), and a dispersion of about 15 %. This approach to DP is unique in that precipitation is caused by incremental removal rather than addition of the base. As NH3 evaporates, the Co ammine decomposes to Co3O4. The preparation of high loadings, e.g., 50 wt% Co, would require the use of a relatively large surface area support to accommodate the large quantity of Co NCs with dCo of 3−5 nm susceptible to sintering via OR during FT reaction; moreover, Co NCs would be closer together, favoring sintering by CMC. Fig. 7 a shows species percentages and transition temperatures to CoO and Co during in situ reduction monitored by XRD; reduction appears to be complete at 600 °C. The data for diffraction of the Co(111) and Co(200) planes in Fig. 7b illustrate the unusual stability of the Co crystallites in hydrogen, i.e., as temperature is increased from 500 to 850 °C, average dCo values increase from 2.5 and 2.8 nm to about 4 and 5 nm respectively. For a 42 wt% Co (% in the oxide form) catalyst tested at a space velocity of 8.70 h−1 and 50 % CO conversion, the following product compositions were observed: 85.1 % C5+, 6.3 % CH4, 7.9 % C2-C4, and 0.3 % CO2. This result is similar to that of a cobalt nitrate impregnated catalyst. In a lifetime test in a continuous stirred tank reactor (CSTR) a significant decrease in CO conversion from 53 % after 100 h to 41 % after only 600 h TOS was observed. The relatively rapid loss of activity could have been caused in part by sintering of the small Co crystallites via OR and larger NCs by CMC in the presence of CO and water [64]. 2.3 Deposition of an oxide or metal on a support via solution combustion synthesis (SCS) Solution combustion synthesis (SCS) was first developed in the mid-1980s [67]. However, its application to preparation of catalysts is relatively new. SCS can be conducted via two routes: (i) volume combustion and (ii) self-propagating combustion. Since catalysts are generally synthesized by volume combustion, this method will be our focus in this section. Several unique features of volume SCS for an unsupported catalyst or catalyst support (Fig. 8 a) include: (a) mixing of an oxidizer (e.g., iron nitrate) and a soluble fuel (e.g., glycine) in either an aqueous or nonaqueous solution and (b) heating of the impregnated catalyst in a ceramic vessel through the following sequence (illustrated in Fig. 8b): (i) uniform preheating of the solution to the boiling point of the solvent; (ii) evaporation of the solvent over a relatively long time at near constant temperature; (iii) heating of the remaining solid mixture over a short time to reach the ignition temperature (Tig), followed immediately by; (iv) combustion of the solid, causing a very sharp rise in temperature and reaching the maximum temperature (Tm) in a second or less; and (v) very rapid, almost instantaneous cooling. Note that the sharp increase in temperature is due to several stages of endo- and largely exothermic decompositions of the fuel (reducing agent) with a large positive heat release due to its oxidation. As the maximum temperature is reached, a large quantity of gaseous products are evolved which cause (a) rapid expansion of the solid increasing its porosity and (b) a sharp decrease in temperature due to the endothermic release of gases. The rapid cooling process increases porosity and formation of NCs in the case of unsupported solids, as in Fig. 8a and b. In SCS, the stoichiometry of reaction may be defined in terms of the ratio of the moles of fuel (nf) to moles of oxidizer (no), which enables the reaction to occur in the absence of oxygen from air. Thus, in reaction 2, involving combustion of Al nitrate and urea, the stoichiometric ratio is nf/no = 5/2. Alternatively, the stoichiometry is defined in terms of the equivalence ratio φ for a redox reaction, i.e., φ = (nf /no)actual/(nf /no)stoich. If φ = 1, the combustion synthesis is stoichiometric; if φ > 1, the redox reaction is on the fuel-rich side. (2) 2Al(NO3)3 9H2O + 5CH4N2O → Al2O3 + 8N2 + 5CO2 + 28H2O It is evident from Fig. 8a and b that a maximum temperature (Tm) of 1200 °C for combustion of a solution of a non-supported catalyst is high enough to cause irreversible damage to most supported catalysts. Fortunately, solution combustion synthesis of supported NCs can be carried out at temperatures as low as 250−300 °C, as suggested by the temperature profile in Fig. 8d. This temperature profile was measured during solution combustion with a thermocouple placed in the bed of the impregnated catalyst in the form of 1 mm spheres [68]. How can combustion occur at this low temperature? In a supported system the impregnated liquid may occupy 30–40 % of the total volume, depending on pore volume. Following evaporation of water, the solid nitrate and organic fuel occupy only a small fraction of the pore volume. Thus, following ignition and a relatively slow rise in the temperature of the relatively small volume of reacting solid, the support still at Tig provides a heat sink for the reacting solid. In addition, the large gas release which occurs during the temperature rise serves to cool the reacting solid and heat the support before it exits the catalyst so that the Tm of 298 °C is only slightly higher than the equilibrated temperature of about 290 °C after cooling (see Fig. 8d). Heat transfer in this low-temperature process is also facilitated by the relatively slow combustion process and temperature rise for the supported catalyst, i.e., approximately 60 min total and 7 min for the temperature rise and cooling (Fig. 8d), compared to about 13 min total for solution combustion in the absence of a support and roughly one second for the temperature rise and cooling (Fig. 8b). While the above description of heat transfer in a supported catalyst is qualitatively reasonable, there are important unknowns, e.g., (i) the quantitative rates and extents of heat transfer among the support, gases, and the reacting solid and (ii) the actual temperature inside the support pores during combustion, which could be much higher than that measured on the outside of the catalyst spheres (Fig. 8d). Fig. 8c illustrates how solution or gel combustion can be used in argon or air to deposit Ni0 or NiO NCs respectively, on the external surfaces of SiO2 particles. Fig. 9 depicts template-assisted synthesis of an oxide in the pores of a support: (A) SBA-15 as a support; (B) impregnation of SBA-15 with a solution containing fuel and oxidizers including water-free Fe nitrate; (C) initiation of combustion in the pores to form α-Fe2O3 NCs in the pores; and (D) spatially uniform adsorption of the oxide NC to the pore walls of the support [95]. Important advantages of volume combustion for preparation of catalysts include (i) its time efficiency; (ii) its flexibility to control the catalyst microstructure by changing combustion conditions e.g., by adjusting relative concentrations of oxidizer and fuel and therewith maximum temperature and cooling rate which determines catalyst physical and chemical properties (including composition, NC size), and in consequence modifying catalyst activity, selectivity and stability; and (iii) the capability of operating at a lower maximum temperature, thus minimizing sintering of the porous solid or supported NCs; and probably most importantly, (iv) the capacity to synthesize doped, complex, supported NCs of very high structural homogeneity and relatively strong binding to the support [67]. However, it’s important to consider that (i) the exothermicity of the process and (ii) the formation of significant quantities of CO, CO2 and hydrocarbon vapors are generally two major concerns in industrial application of SCS method. Several recent papers [68,96–101] have focused on the preparation of Co FT catalysts via volume combustion under reducing and oxidizing conditions. Shi et al. [97–99] studied solution combustion synthesis (SCS), via calcination in argon or air at 450 °C of silica previously impregnated with a solution containing cobalt nitrate, dried, and impregnated with citric acid. Combustion synthesized catalysts were studied as a function of citric acid/cobalt nitrate ratio. A 15 wt% Co/SiO2 catalyst prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI, same as DI) was used as a reference. Catalyst properties were determined by a number of techniques, including TPR, H2 chemisorption to determine Co site density, and TGA to determine extent of reduction, from which dCo was estimated. CO conversion and methane selectivity were measured for the reduced, passivated catalysts in a CSTR. Catalysts using SCS at a citric acid /Co nitrate ratio of 1.5 and calcined at 450 °C in argon produced well-reduced Co NCs for which dCo was about 3−6 nm, while for the catalyst prepared by IWI, calcined and reduced at 450 °C, average dCo was about 30 nm. In the TPR spectrum of an SCS catalyst (citric acid/Co nitrate ratio of 1.5) previously calcined in argon at 450 °C, a broad peak at about 427−627 °C was observed, which was assigned to the hydrogenation of amorphous carbon in the presence of metallic Co. For catalyst precursors combusted in air or air/Ar at 450 °C and then reduced at 450 °C, dCo values were 13 or 8.5 nm respectively [97]. CO conversions for catalysts calcined in argon or air were 42–64 % or 46 % respectively, CH4 selectivities were 40 or 9.8–11.6 % respectively, and CO2 selectivities were 7.8 or 4.6–5.2 % respectively. Thus, the catalysts combusted in air were apparently as active as the ones combusted in Ar, but the catalysts calcined in air had much lower CH4 selectivities. The high CH4 selectivity (40 %) for the catalysts calcined in argon was attributed to (i) small NCs of 3−6 nm and (ii) an amorphous carbon deposit with a higher pore diffusional resistance for CO than H2 and hence a high H2/CO ratio at the Co NC surface, both of which conditions are known to favor high CH4 selectivity. For the catalyst prepared by IWI, CO conversion was only 16.7 %, CH4 selectivity was 11.6 %, and CO2 selectivity was 1.3 %, indicating that this catalyst was much less active but had more favorable selectivities. The comparison made in these studies of catalyst activity between SCS catalysts and the IWI catalyst was highly problematic, since the reference IWI catalyst was calcined at 450 °C, an abnormally high temperature for calcination of such a catalyst. Generally, Co/SiO2 catalysts prepared by IWI are calcined at 250−350 °C to prevent sintering during their preparation. Moreover, detailed methods/conditions for drying, calcination, and reduction were not reported and were probably not optimized; a typical range of dCo for IWI Co/SiO2 catalysts prepared under milder, optimal conditions would be 8−10 nm; thus, in a valid comparison, CO conversion and activity for the IWI catalyst would probably be as high or higher, while CH4 selectivity would be 5−10 %. TEM micrographs of the reduced, passivated SCS catalysts (citric acid /Co nitrate = 1.5) calcined initially (a) in Ar and (b) in Ar/air, are shown in Fig. 10 . Values of dCo for the two catalyst are: (a) about 2−5 nm and (b) 5−10 nm. Spatial distributions of Co NCs are (a) remarkably even and (b) acceptably even. The observation of small to medium Co NCs (3−10 nm) and their favorable spatial distributions indicate that these catalysts are probably resistant to sintering. In the catalyst calcined in argon (Fig. 10a) dark circles, covering parts of the surface, may consist of amorphous, graphitic carbon which the authors identified as reducible only at about 700–900 °C. Thus, SCS in air is likely to provide the optimal catalyst properties and performace. Two papers by Ail et al. [68,101] and a PhD thesis by Ail [100] describe studies of SCS of Co nitrate with hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA) on alumina and silica-alumina supports. They prepared solutions of Co nitrate (equivalent to 20 wt% Co) and HMTA with equivalence ratios of φ = 1.0, 1.2, and 1.5, which were impregnated into the supports and heated in air at 10 °C/min to 400 °C. Formation of large quantities of Co-aluminate were observed which can be explained by (i) attempting to prepare a 20 wt% Co catalyst in a single step, which caused a large release of heat and water during the combustion reaction; and (ii) flowing air during combustion which increased the available concentration of the oxygen in the combustion reaction leading to greater heat release; and (iii) a high heating rate up to 400 °C. We suggest that preparation of a 10 wt% Co catalyst in Ar or Ar/Air mixtures with a lower heating rate up to an optimal, lower temperature may avoid these problems. The preparation could be repeated to obtain higher Co loadings. A comparison was made against a reference catalyst prepared by IWI and calcined and reduced at 400 °C; thus, their comparison was invalid in the same ways as discussed above for Shi et al. [97–99] The validity of their conversion and selectivity data must also be questioned, since 6 g of catalyst was used in the catalyst testing; the authors claimed that mixing of a large excess of SiC with the catalyst would enable isothermal operation. However, it clearly could not. In fact, the thesis of Ail. [100] explains that using sophisticated temperature control methods, the temperature cycled over a range of 10 °C, which is quite unacceptable for catalyst activity/selectivity testing. The most successful application of SCS to Co catalyst preparation has been accomplished through a joint collaboration of Velocys and Oxford Catalysts in the development of the most active, selective, and productive commercial Co FT catalyst to date. [96,102–105] Richard et al. [102] studied effects of crystallite size on activity and of spatial distribution on deactivation rate for a Co/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst prepared by SCS, apparently by using urea as the fuel by reference to a 2008 patent assigned to Oxford Catalysts [103]. Their preparation method is referred to as “the proprietary ‘organic matrix combustion’ (OMx) method,” a self-sustained reaction of a metal salt with an organic fuel. In the OMx method, control of reaction rate, catalyst composition, NC size, and pore structure of catalysts was said to occur “by varying the thermochemistry of the reaction, e.g., rates of heat release and combustion temperature.” It is also clear from their paper [102] and U.S. patent [103] that precise control of the combustion step is achieved by using relatively low concentrations of Co nitrate and fuel, which impregnated solution is first carefully dried at 2 °C/min to 100 °C and held there for 3−5 h followed by a mild, programmed calcination at 2 °C/min to 200 °C, holding there for 3 h followed by ramping to 250 °C at 2 °C/min to 250 °C and holding there for 1 h. The impregnation, drying and calcination are repeated 4−6 times to achieve the desired Co metal loading of up to 45 wt%. The use of ZrO2-stabilized SiO2 support with an average pore diameter of 13 nm facilitates preparation of a Co catalyst having an optimal dCo of 10 nm. Richard et al. [102] demonstrated that for a Co/ZrO2SiO2 catalyst prepared by OMx, (i) the apparent turnover frequency for FT increases linearly with dCo from 3 to 10 nm, and (ii) deactivation rate versus the width of the size distribution of the Co3O4 particles increases through a maximum, forming a volcano plot. The latter correlation predicts that the minimum deactivation rate occurs for a medium-wide size distribution, a result that is counter-intuitive, since the conventional wisdom is that a very narrow size distribution provides the maximum resistance to sintering. Nevertheless, by changing conditions of the preparation to produce the optimal dCo of 10 nm and NC size distribution, a high-activity, stable catalyst was prepared and tested (see Fig. 11 ). At a temperature of 207 °C the catalyst was reported to have an initial activity of 0.25 molCO/gCo-h and a CO conversion of 70–72 % over 2000 h (83 days), during which time the deactivation rate of was only −0.08 % CO converted/day compared with a variation of -0.8 to -2.3 CO converted/day for the other catalysts whose deactivation formed the original volcano plot. The results suggest that an optimized Co crystallite diameter of 10 nm [105] could have completely or almost completely prevented sintering. The authors acknowledge (i) a significant flaw in estimating Co NM size from Co3O4 size, assuming Co0 NC size = 0.75 × Co3O4 NC size; indeed, Cook et al. [106,107] observed d C o 0 / d C o 3 O 4 ratios from TEM for alumina-supported Co, CoPt, CoRe, and CoRu catalysts of 0.92, 0.87, 1.29, and 0.60 respectively, all prepared using the same method and support; and (ii) that there could be other unmeasured structural or chemical, e.g., poisoning of sites by carbon atoms or carbon oligomers, factors other than NC size distribution that could affect the deactivation rate. Further improvements to Oxford Co catalysts, methods of preparation, catalyst properties, and activity/selectivity data are reported in recent patents [104,105] assigned to Oxford Catalysts. Enhancements in catalyst design included (i) optimizing the percentage of TiO2 to stabilize the SiO2 support; (ii) optimizing the catalyst formulation to lower methane selectivity to 5.2 % and increase C5+ to 90.7 % at a CO conversion of 70 %, including a higher range of dCo of 9−11 nm, higher porosity of 0.36, and a composition of 42–46 % Co/0.3 % Re/10 % TiO2/SiO2; (iii) a new method of support preparation using solution combustion; and (iv) a mixture of Co nitrate and citric or lactic acid in concentrations such that solution combustion ends at 250 °C. 2.4 Preferred methods, precautions and recommendations Deposition methods of precursors into support pores should be formulated to produce a homogeneous layer of metal precursor into the support pores. Each of the three methods of metal precursor deposition discussed in this paper including impregnation, deposition precipitation, and solution combustion synthesis have advantages and disadvantages. These advantages and disadvantages are summarized in section 4.2. Selecting among these methods depends on technical advantages/disadvantages, catalyst performance, and the economics of the scaled-up preparation method. The more steps in the preparation, the higher that cost. Most commercial Co FT catalysts are prepared by impregnation. Relative simplicity, rapidity, capability for depositing the precursor at moderately-high loadings (e.g., 10 % for Co nitrate impregnation in the mesopores of an oxidic support) are the main reasons for tendency of commercial catalyst manufacturing companies towards this method. In using this method it’s important to carefully perform experimental design to optimize the adhesion energy between NC and support by changing the variables such as: (i) impregnation solution; (ii) Co nanocrystal precursor; (iii) promoter metal type and precursor; (iv) rotary evaporator and/or mixing operating parameters. Deposition precipitation method has proved promising at the laboratory scale due to (i) a favorable one-step route to achieving moderate to high loadings, i.e. 20–50 wt % and higher or comparable Co dispersions; (ii) a uniform distribution of the active precursor inside support pores in a well-dispersed phase, a good fraction of which is moderately strongly held to the support surface; and (iii) Co NCs are less mobile because of their moderately-high Eadh and the significant presence of surface oxide NCs. Nevertheless, this method has not been used to prepare commercial Co FT catalysts. Moreover, few data are available on activity/selectivity stability. Experimental design for deposition precipitation should take into account the temperature, pH, reagent type selection for nucleation, and mixing speed to ensure homogenous nucleation. The most highly successful application of solution combustion synthesis (SCS) to Co catalyst preparation has been accomplished through a joint collaboration of Velocys and Oxford Catalysts in the development of the most active, selective, and productive commercial Co FT catalyst to date [96,102–105]. The key to this development is precise control of the combustion step by using (i) relatively low concentrations of Co nitrate and fuel and (ii) precise temperature programmed drying and calcination to a low temperature of 250 °C. The main drawback is that 5−8 impregnations are necessary to achieve a sufficiently high loading of Co. 3 Effects of drying, calcination, and reduction on catalyst properties important in sintering 3.1 Drying It is well known in the art and science of catalyst preparation that active metal distribution, catalyst properties, and performance of catalysts prepared by impregnation depend extensively on the choice of drying conditions [72,108]. Over the past 40 years, substantial progress has been made in understanding effects of drying on macro-radial-distributions of impregnated catalysts in catalyst pellets, much of which is addressed in chapter 15 by Geus [74] and chapter 16 by Lekhal et al. [72] and the references therein, from the book of Regalbuto [3]. Until recently, there was little information on effects of drying at the nanoscale. Several recent papers [109–113] provide definitive data relevant to effects of drying at the macro, meso, and nanoscale. Drying of impregnated catalysts is carried out at temperatures ranging from 50 to 150 °C to remove the solvent; 100 °C is probably optimal for many supported metal precursors [43]. During drying, the precursor can be redistributed by adsorption of the precursor or metal ions, capillary flow, and diffusion. To avoid sintering, drying should result in a spatially-uniform profile. Drying is a three-step process consisting of preheating, drying at constant rate, and completion during a falling rate period as illustrated in Fig. 12 a for ideal conditions. Ideal is defined as a uniformly thin sample in which the rate of moisture is uniformly removed over its entire surface by flowing purified air or N2 at high rates either through or over the sample. Fig. 12b shows variations in drying rate at different external temperatures as predicted by the comprehensive drying model of Lekhal et al. [109] The three stages of drying rate are evident for all drying temperatures; the preheating stage (increasing rate) occurs rapidly in roughly the same time frame of about 100−500 s for all drying temperatures, while the time intervals of the constant rate and falling rate stages decrease with increasing drying temperature. During the constant rate stage, the solvent evaporates in close proximity to the external surface. Drying rate remains constant as long as capillary flow of the solution continues to wet the surface. The third stage (falling rate) begins as capillary flow decreases and the drying front recedes, at which point, back diffusion and redistribution of dissolved precursors is able to occur, which given sufficient time, can produce a homogeneous distribution. From Fig. 12b drying times are about 24, 12.5, 6.9, and 4.5 h for 50, 100, 150, and 200 °C respectively. It should be noted that complications are sometimes observed when drying at 200 °C, since anhydrous Co nitrate can decompose violently to large NCs of Co3O4 at 185−195 °C in air if conditions are not carefully controlled. Fig. 13 illustrates the transport mechanisms (physical and chemical processes) which govern the redistribution of adsorbed catalyst precursors. Of these, the most important are (i) adsorption of metal precursors (solute) onto the support, (ii) transport of the solvent, (iii) transport of dissolved species in the solvent via convective or back-diffusion mechanisms, (iv) heat transport inside the particle, and (v) heat and mass transport at the surface of the support particle. Each of these processes is discussed in detail by Lekhal et al. [72]. A number of published models have been developed for simulating drying rates and the final adsorbed metal precursor profiles [72,109]. The previous model studies and their contributions to the understanding of drying are reviewed in some detail by the same group [109]. A comprehensive drying model was published in 2001 by Lekhal et al. [109]. It provides (i) an overall picture of the physical and chemical properties that affects distribution of a catalyst precursor during drying, including effects of drying temperature, permeability (resistance of a material to fluid diffusion determined by pore structure), and diffusivity (constant in the rate equation for diffusion) of metal ions on radial precursor deposition profiles for weak, moderate, and strong adsorption of the precursor; (ii) quantitative maps of dimensionless diffusion rate versus dimensionless convection rate (capillary flow) for strongly adsorbed and weakly adsorbed catalyst precursors showing regions of uniform radial, egg-shell, and egg-yolk distributions; (iii) equations for adsorption, heat/mass transport, effects of temperature, and permeability (function of pore size distribution, pore shape, connectivity, and tortuosity) on catalyst distribution during drying; (iv) a table summarizing adsorption models for drying and discussion of drying models, (v) references to effects of drying at the nanoscale, including NC size and structure and interaction with the support; and (vi) drying equipment and technologies. Drying of two component systems and effects of ionic strength and pH are addressed in more comprehensive models [112,113]. The single-component drying model [109] is based on (i) a support having the following properties: an apparent density of 981 kg/m3, a porosity of 0.687, and a catalyst particle diameter of 1 cm; (ii) an aqueous impregnating solution containing a Ni salt having an initial concentration of 100 mol/m3; and (iii) initial conditions of T0 = 20 °C and P0 = 1 atm. The acidity of the solution is assumed to be constant. Metal precursor profiles are shown in Fig. 14 after drying at at 50, 100, 150, and 200 °C. After drying at 50 °C the metal profile is uniformly horizontal through each catalyst particle. As drying temperature increases incrementally to 100, 150, and 200 °C the dried catalyst precursor develops a progressively narrower eggshell profile. The drying curves and metal precursor profiles shown in Figs. 12b and 14 are predicted by the model for a specific set of parameters (C0 = 100 mol/m3 is a low concentration giving a 3.6 % Ni loading). Thus, the final precursor profile is predicted to vary for different starting physical and chemical properties of the impregnated support and transport properties; for example, Lekhal et al. [109] demonstrated that by increasing precursor diffusivity by factors of 10 and 100 (other properties unchanged), uniform, horizontal profiles were predicted for a drying temperature of 100 °C for low, medium and high values of Keq (the equilibrium constant for adsorption). After examining the effects of several model parameters on radial profiles, Lekhal et al. [109] observed that: i The metal redistribution during the drying stage is a result of complex interactions of different phenomena. ii In general, the final catalyst profile is determined by the relative magnitudes of evaporation rate, convective flow (due to capillary forces) and dissolved metal precursor diffusion for weak or moderate adsorption; if adsorption is strong, drying affects the metal profile only slightly. Liu et al. [111,115] extended the drying model of Lekhal et al. [109] to address broader issues, including effects of heating rate (a positive function of drying temperature) and metal loading on final radial distributions of Ni nitrate in γ-Al2O3. In the first of these papers [115] the authors extended the model to include (i) external drying by air; (ii) metal distribution profiles during impregnation and their effects on metal distribution profiles obtained during drying; (iii) effects of drying temperature, air flowrate, and air humidity on final metal profiles, and (iv) effects of metal precursor crystallization at high metal loadings on generation of eggshell profiles. In Fig. 15 , final metal-precursor radial profiles are shown as functions of (a) drying temperature, (b) humidity, and (c) catalyst particle diameter, each of which is referenced to the initial profile after impregnation (for weak adsorption and a moderately high support permeability). Final radial profiles tend to be flatter at a low drying temperature, high humidity, and small catalyst particle size, while for the inverse of these properties, final profiles tend toward eggshell-like. Effects of the three controlling drying parameters (drying temperature, humidity, and flow rate) are similar, i.e., similar nearly flat profiles can be observed by decreasing drying temperature, increasing humidity, or decreasing air flow rate. However, the combination of these conditions, especially high humidity, lead to very slow drying. Simulations were performed for a commercially-viable drying strategy in which humidity is lowered in increments from 30 % to 1% over drying time, which greatly reduces drying time (profiles are not shown in the this paper). In commercial operations, drying temperature, humidity and flow rates are varied to produce the desired profile over a short period of time, thereby saving operating costs and energy. Based on their simulations, Liu et al. [115] found that precursor diffusivity and drying temperature most extensively impact metal precursor redistribution. A contour map of final profiles is plotted in Fig. 16 as a function of diffusivity versus drying temperature (calculations valid for initial metal precursor concentration in the impregnation solution C0 = 0.25 M, weak adsorption, and a moderately high permeability). A drying temperature below 100 °C and a diffusivity above about 20−30 × 10−10 m2/s favors a uniform profile, while at a temperature above 100 °C and a diffusivity below 20 × 10−10 m2/s an eggshell profile is predicted; above 100 °C and at a diffusivity lower than about 5 × 10−10 m2/s, a sharp eggshell profile is predicted. In the second paper [111], it was found that at high metal loadings, the model must account for additional phenomena, including effects of metal precursor concentration on solution density, viscosity, water vapor pressure and liquid surface tension. Thus, the drying profile for a high metal loading catalyst differs substantially from that of a low metal loading catalyst. For example, the constant rate period observed during drying of low metal loading catalysts is absent during drying of high metal loading catalysts. Profiles in Fig. 17 a and b at 25 °C for a 1.8 wt% Ni/Al2O3 and an 18 wt% Ni/Al2O3 are both uniform. However, an eggshell distribution is predicted and observed for a 1.8 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst in Fig. 17c, while an acceptably uniform metal distribution is predicted and observed for an 18 wt% Ni/Al2O3 in Fig. 17d, both at a higher drying temperature of 80 °C. Munnik et al. [43] observed (by TEM) nanoscale distributions of 8 nm diameter Co3O4 crystallites in a 17 wt% Co/ SiO2 (SA = 443 m2/g, Vpore = 0.87 cm3/g, and dpore = 8 nm, prepared by wet impregnation with Co nitrate) as a function of drying temperature; they observed substantial nanoscale clustering of Co crystallites following drying at either low (25−75 °C) or very high (125−150 °C) temperatures. Nevertheless, drying at an intermediate temperature of 100 °C for 6 h produced the most uniform nanoscale distribution of Co; moreover, the catalyst dried at 100 °C was the most active of the catalysts dried at low to high temperatures (see Fig. 18 ). Our interpretation of the discussion by Munnik et al. [43] is that, at temperatures below 100 °C aggregation was attributed to slow drying with considerable inhomogeneous redistribution of the liquid forming pools so that upon removal of the liquid the precipitated phase consists of regions of high and low concentrations of solid cobalt nitrate. During calcination the highly concentrated regions produce clusters of large Co3O4 NCs. Above 100 °C, rapid and non uniform drying of the liquid to produce Co nitrate which at these high temperatures forms a melt which has high mobility causes inhomogeneous pools of melts that nucleate and grow at different rates, forming large Co3O4 aggregates. Munnik et al. [116] demonstrated that an initial, uniform, spatial distribution of Co NCs results in less sintering during reaction. They also found that drying temperature plays a key role in controlling the uniformity of spatial distributions of NCs prepared by impregnation methods and that 100 °C is the optimal temperature for drying Co nitrate supported on silica gel when impregnated grains are dried in an upflow fluidized bed reactor (internal diameter of 1 or 2 cm,) located inside an oven with 5000 h−1 gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of N2 (see example in Fig. 18). Before leaving the topic of drying, some practical aspects of laboratory and commercial practice should be mentioned. Hoffman [110] commented that (i) the product temperature profile is more useful than the dryer temperature in predicting and preventing sample overdrying, thereby lowering energy consumption and (ii) by varying both air volume and temperature over process time, the efficiency of the drying process is improved and operating cost is decreased. The viscosity of the solution and strength of adsorption of the precursor can be used to increase uniformity of metal dispersion or create an eggshell or eggyolk distribution of which examples are cited by Geus [74] and Lekhal et al. [72] Uniformity of the deposition of active metal precursors is said to be improved by incorporating organic additives, the viscosity of which increases as the impregnating solution becomes more concentrated [74]. However, these additives may pose safety problems during calcination (see Section 3.2). Lekhal et al. [72] briefly reviewed drying technologies, while Stiles and Koch [114] discussed drying equipment in significant detail. Although drying in a fluidized bed [116] or a rotary kiln [114] is described in previous literature, Lekhal et al. [74] recommended against use of drying units involving mixing of solids because of potential mechanical damage such as abrasion or attrition. In the laboratory, impregnated catalysts should be generally dried in a vacuum, heat convective, or circulating air oven; [114] air or N2 flow and catalyst temperature should be carefully controlled. In the latter two oven types, humid air is preferably exhausted through an opening at the top. For all three oven types it is strongly recommended that catalyst samples be housed in a shallow ceramic or stainless-steel tray having a depth less than 2 cm; our laboratory has fabricated trays of fine stainless steel wire mesh having a depth less than 1 cm which enables flowing air to flow through or on all sides to completely contact the sample. A more sophisticated oven featuring an inlet and outlet for use of N2 or other inert gases as the drying medium is also recommended. Stiles and Koch [114] described details of drying equipment for pilot and plant-scale drying equipment, including cubical (with door, heater or heat exchanger, and fan), tray-rack, continuous-belt, tunnel (continuous processing over a wide range of temperature for drying and calcining), rotary drum (for high throughput drying of aluminas, zeolites, or other supports; although temperature is poorly controlled), flash, and spray dryers (the last for production of microsphere fluidized- and slurry-bed catalysts). Each of these dryers has specific applications, advantages, and limitations. Cubical dryers are the simplest, low-cost dryers but are potentially subject to contamination of the catalyst; tray-rack and continuous-belt dryers are probably the most flexible, precise, and widely-used dryers for pilot and plant-scale drying plants respectively. The continuous-belt dryer is a low-pressure-drop dryer, especially useful for drying of extrudates when its velocity is synchronized with the discharge rate of the extruder. It can be easily adapted to a continuous drying and calcination train; however, it is custom-designed and thus very expensive at the pilot scale, although more economical at the plant scale. 3.1.1 Preferred methods, precautions and recommendations Drying is an important step in determining the distribution of metal precursor; if not done carefully, it can cause redistribution of homogeneous distribution of metal precurosor after a uniform deposition to a nonhomogeneous one. Drying of impregnated catalysts is generally carried out in flowing air at temperatures ranging from 50 to 150 °C to remove the solvent. High distribution of dried metallic precursor over the support is obtained using a thin sample in which the rate of moisture is uniformly removed over its entire surface by flowing air or N2 of adequate humidity to prevent rapid, non-uniform drying, either through or over the sample. Fluid bed, rotary, and conveyor dryers are three commonly used dryers in industry. An experimental design to optimize the drying process for a given dryer and an impregnated support should consider (i) drying temperature; (ii) drying time; (iii) humidity; and (iv) catalyst bed thickness. All of these parameters will vary by a change in: (i) precursor loading; (ii) support properties; (iii) impregnating solution concentration. 3.2 Calcination The objectives of calcination of an impregnated and previously-dried, supported Co catalyst are to gently dehydrate and decompose the adsorbed metal precursor, typically partially hydrated Co(NO3)2, to form oxide NCs, e.g., Co3O4, which can be subsequently reduced to supported NCs of Co metal which are spatially uniform, having a sharp crystallite distribution, and a near optimal average dCo. This section focuses on the following aspects of calcination from the previous literature (i) mechanisms, intermediates, and their implications; (ii) effects of heating rate, final temperature, and atmosphere on catalyst physical and chemical properties; and (iii) preferred methods, precautions, and recommendations. Temperature programmed methods (TPO, TPN2, TPR; O refers to oxidation, N2 refers to thermal treatement in nitrogen, R to reduction), including gravimetric methods, have been used for more than four decades to study phase transitions, mechanisms, and rates of transformations and decomposition of solids, e.g., dehydration, calcination, and reduction of catalysts [117–120]. TPO and TPN2 have been used to study calcination of dried Co catalysts in air and nitrogen. It will be shown how TPO or TPN2 patterns, along with other forms of spectroscopy, can be employed in revealing stoichiometric reactions, intermediates, and optimal conditions for calcination of supported impregnated and dried Co nitrate. 3.2.1 Reaction chemistry, intermediates, and mechanistic insights Several early TPO and TPN2 studies, conducted at relatively high heating rates (3−10 °C /min), addressed the decomposition of Co(NO3)2∙6H2O in air or N2. Malecki et al. [121] reported that Co2O3∙H2O was formed as an intermediate in the formation of Co3O4. El-Shobaky et al. [122] reported that the alumina-supported hexahydrate decomposed at a lower temperature than the unsupported material; decomposition to Co3O4/Al2O3 at 200 °C was observed. Mansour [123] reported that Co(NO3)2∙6H2O decomposes in four steps: (i) melting at 75 °C, (ii) dehydration between 80 and 170 °C forming Co nitrate monohydrate, (iii) dehydration of the monohydrate and decomposition to Co(NO3)2, CoO, Co2O3, and Co3O4 above 170 °C, and (iv) formation of only Co3O4 at 240 °C. Cseri et al. [124] found that rapid Co nitrate decomposition proceeds to Co3O4 with the release of NO2, H2O, and O2. Girardon et al. [83] used TPO/DSC, finding that Co nitrate/SiO2 (10 wt% Co) decomposes in the range of 140−160 °C to Co3O4. Hong et al. [125] heated a Co nitrate impregnated silica at 2 °C/min in air or N2, observing that anhydrous Co(NO3)2/SiO2 formed at 140 °C; this formation was said to be followed by a rapid, “brutal” decomposition of the nitrate due to release of O2, which concluded at 200 °C; it was suggested that the O2 caused formation of large Co3O4 NCs. The results from these Co nitrate decomposition studies are in poor agreement regarding temperatures of dehydration, decomposition, and formation of intermediate species. The reported temperatures for formation of Co3O4 range from 140 to 240 °C. These wide-ranging results derive from different experimental conditions, Co concentrations, support types and properties, a range of undesirably-high heating rates, and various degrees of dryness. The observation [122] that alumina-supported Co hexahydrate decomposes at a lower temperature than the pure salt is possibly true but uncertain because of the high heating rate used. In a sophisticated, definitive, gravimetric study of Co nitrate decomposition, Ehrhardt et al. [126] used a magnetic suspension balance in which the sample compartment was isolated from the balance enabling decomposition reactions and corrosive products such as NOx to be studied. Computer software was used to decrease heating rate proportional to mass loss, thereby enabling stepwise quasi-isothermal operation for 7−30 h during each decomposition step; in between isothermal steps, the heating ramp was 0.6 °C/min.
