The authors [126] found that (i) unsupported Co(NO3)2∙6H2O, undergoes stepwise formation in N2 of the tetra- and di-hydrate and anhydrous Co(NO3)2 at regular intervals of temperature, i.e., 35, 67, and 110 °C (308, 340, and 383 K); (ii) upon further heating in N2 unsupported, anhydrous Co(NO3)2, decomposition to Co2O3 occurs partwise at 185 °C (458 K) and to Co3O4 at 200 °C (473 K) (see Fig. 19 a and Table 4 ); Co2O3∙H2O was not observed; (iii) besides the Co(NO3)2 intermediate, NO[Co(NO3)3] (nitrosyl nitratocobaltate or more formally “nitrosonium nitratocobaltate”) is formed at about the same temperature as Co(NO3)2 and decomposes to Co3O4 at 200 °C (473 K) as seen in Fig. 19b; reaction 6 in Table 4 indicates that the the nitrosyl species can alternately decompose to Co(NO3)2 and 2 mol of NO2 (either path is consistent with Fig. 19b); (iv) nitrogen oxides are formed in reactions 4a, 4b, and 6 consistent with the observed evolution of NO and NO2 during Co nitrate decomposition (N2O4 and N2O5 species are intermediates in equilibrium with NO2 and NO); and (v) a side product, [Co(NO3)2]2O, is formed when the TGA sample mass is substantially increased, which was attributed to a higher PH2O (see Fig. 19a and reaction 3a Table 4); decomposition of the oxide (reaction 3b) produces Co(NO3)2 and oxygen, the latter being an undersirable product. Ehrhardt et al. [126] noted that rapid heating of Co nitrate hexahydrate causes a hydrate melt substantially altering the system through side reactions and evaporation of HNO3 and other species. The results of the study of Ehrhardt et al. [126] establish definitive fundamental insights into and quantitative data for Co nitrate decomposition showing that slow heating in N2 with isothermal pauses at 35, 67, and 110 °C produces anhydrous Co(NO2) which decomposes to Co2O3 at 183 °C and to Co3O4 at 200 °C, and thus a well-defined, safe route for calcination. Nevertheless, this approach consumes a great deal of time, although methods to streamline this approach could be developed. Moreover, a similar, comprehensive study of the decomposition of Co nitrate-impregnated, commercially-representative, large-pore, stabilized alumina and silica supports, after drying up to 100 °C, is needed to determine if and/or how supports affect this network of reactions. A number of studies (examples discussed below) demonstrate that formation of intermediates and high dispersion are highly dependent on the gas atmosphere during calcination. Wolters et al. [127] explored effects of gas composition and flow versus stagnant air during calcination of silica supported Ni and cobalt nitrates dried at 120 °C, finding that a 1 mol% NO/He gas flow yields the highest and stagnant air the lowest dispersion. Using in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and XRD, it was found that during precalcination in flowing N2 or O2/N2, a mixture of metal-hydroxynitrates and metal-nitrate hydrates was formed between 100 and 150 °C, whereas flowing NO/He facilitated complete hydrolysis to hydroxynitrates of reduced mobility during decomposition. These results indicate that increased formation of hydroxynitrates is a key to the high dispersions of NiO and Co3O4 obtained in dilute NO. Hong et al. [125] studied decomposition of Co(NO3)2∙6H2O/SiO2 in 5% NO/N2, observing formation of a hydroxynitrate Co(OH)3(NO3) intermediate at about 90 °C, which decomposes rapidly between 170 and 200 °C to small crystallites of Co3O4, thereby contributing to a higher activity for the reduced catalyst relative to reduced catalysts previously calcined in N2 or air. This result is consistent with the work of Sietsma et al. [128] who previously reported that calcination in 1 mol% NO/N2 of Co/SBA-15-SiO2 produces higher dispersions of Co3O4 and subsequently during reduction smaller Co NCs than for catalysts calcined in air or N2. Nevertheless, it should be emphasized that the objective is formation of an average, optimal Co3O4 NC diameter, with sharp size and spatially uniform distributions. Munnik et al. [43] also examined the effects of different thermal treatments on the spatial distribution of Co NCs over silica gel and suggested low-temperature (between 100–150 °C) [127] NO-induced surface-immobilization as method for increasing interactions between the support surface and metal-precursor solution. NO-enhanced hydrolysis of metal nitrates at low temperature is hypothesized to form the immobile compound (Mx(OH)y(NO3)z) for which M can be Co, Ni, or Cu. A further increase in temperature to about 200 °C causes oxygen removal by NO and formation of small Co oxide NCs. A comprehensive study by Becker et al. [129] addressed effects of temperature-programmed calcination (TPC) of 20 wt% Co/1 wt% Re/Al2O3 at different NO/N2 concentrations below 1 mol% NO and included measurements of outlet NO and NO2 concentrations with temperature; their results show that (i) calcination in 1,000–10,000 ppm NO/N2 is a promising route; (ii) it proceeds through formation of a Co hydroxynitrate intermediate at 50−140 °C (see Eq. (3), and was said to facilitate decomposition of the intermediate to Co3O4 Eq. (4) at lower temperatures than by calcination in N2 only; (iii) rates of consumption of NO (Fig. 20 a) and production of NO2 (Fig. 20b) consist of mainly two peaks (some with shoulders); the maximum temperature of the first peak increases with decreasing NO inlet concentration, although the second peak ends at about 250 °C, independent of NO inlet concentration. The first and second major peaks for each of the patterns in Fig. 20a and b are said to correspond to Eqs. (3) and (4) respectively; in other words, the intermediate is formed at the lowest temperature for the highest NO concentration; and (iv) increases in Co surface area of 25 % and 33 % are observed for catalyst samples calcined in 1000 and 10,000 ppm NO/N2 relative to a sample calcined in pure N2. However, since use of NO during calcination, even at a low concentration of 1000 ppm, may be impractical for large scale preparation due to scrubber size and cost, we propose an alternative approach at the end of this section. (3) 4Co(NO3)2(H2O)6 + 3NO → 2Co2(OH)3NO3 + 9NO2 + 21H2O (4) 6Co2(OH)3(NO3) → 4Co3O4 + 5NO2 + NO + 9H2O In a US patent [130] describing calcination of a 7−16 wt% Co/Re catalyst supported on an Al2O3 and SiO2-stabilized TiO2, Soled et al. [130] claim a calcination method for producing a Co nitrosyl intermediate in a first decomposition step which is subsequently hydrolyzed and then either calcined (followed by reduction) or directly reduced in a second decomposition step to produce a spatially uniform distribution of Co NCs also having a narrow crystallite size distribution (CSD). The method involves thorough drying of the impregnated catalyst in air, followed by heating in dry air at 4 °C/min to 160 °C and holding at 160 °C for 1 h (in a box furnace) to disperse the intermediate over the support, after which it is cooled to room temperature and exposed to humid air overnight to decompose the intermediate. The hydrolyzed catalyst is then either calcined at 300 °C for 1−2 h followed by reduction in pure H2 at 375 °C, or directly reduced in pure H2 at 375 °C. For reduced catalysts prepared by this method, the volume/surface averaged diameters are 8.2 ± 2.2 nm and 7.7 ± 2.2 nm respectively. It appears that this method would be too time consuming for commercial preparations, but the information in the patent provides a basis for designing practical methods. The Co nitrosyl intermediate formed at 160 ± 5 °C was identified by FTIR peaks in the range of 1820-1877 cm−1. The precise temperature for its formation was determined by thermal gravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TG/DTA) by heating a sample at 1 °C/min from room temperature to 400 °C, the results of which are shown in Fig. 21 . The DTA curve (blue) consists of three endotherms: (i) the first large endotherm which occurs from room temperature to about 150 °C, is due to loss of water; and (ii) the second and third endotherms from about 150 to about 225 °C correspond to the two steps in the decomposition of anhydrous Co nitrate. The two endotherms occur at approximately the same temperatures as the exotherms for the formation of NO and NO2 (green and red curves). Formation of the Co nitrosyl intermediate occurs while heating through the first decomposition endotherm at about 165−170 °C. While conveying valuable information on the chemistry of calcination, most of the above studies were focused on procedures that produce smaller Co crystallites associated with higher activity. The implications of higher sintering rates for smaller crystallites were not addressed. Moreover, of the above studies, only the patent of Soled et al. [131] considered effects of their procedures on spatial distribution, although it is conceivable that calcination procedures designed to produce intermediates which decompose under mild conditions could facilitate spatially homogeneous spreading of oxide NCs over the support surface. This latter hypothesis is borne out to some extent in the studies described below. 3.2.2 Effects of heating rate, final temperature, atmosphere, flow rate, and heat flow during calcination on catalyst physical and chemical properties The previous discussion of mechanisms and intermediates also addresses to some extent effects of heating rate, atmosphere, and final calcination temperature on dispersion and in several cases on spatial distribution. For example, it was shown in several of these studies that calcination in NO can influence the temperature and rate of nitrate decomposition to produce highly-dispersed and in one study [130] how TGA/FTIR data can be used to produce spatially well-distributed Co3O4 NCs. This section addresses further empirical, parametric studies showing effects of these three factors (above), and of flow rate on chemical and physical properties of the calcined and/or reduced products. Munnik et al. [116] examined the effects of temperature ramp rate during calcination on the spatial distribution of Co oxide NCs in a catalyst with a nominal Co loading of 16.2 wt%. They observed that a high ramp rate (10 °C/min) results in agglomeration of Co oxide NCs, while, a slow temperature ramp rate (1 °C/min) during calcination proved to be crucial for preparation of Co NCs with controlled size and ideal spatial distribution. Loosdrecht et al. [132] conducted a systematic study of the effects of heating rate, gas space velocity, and catalyst bed height during calcination to 250 °C on the relative (initial) intrinsic activity factor (RIAF; after 15 h of FTS) of 23 % Co/Al2O3 and 22 % Co/SiO2-Al2O3. Calcination was conducted in a stationary bed, rotary kiln, or fluidized bed. Parameters were varied as follows: bed depth from 3 to 30 mm, space velocity from 0.26 to 4.5 m3 air/(kg Co(NO3)2·6 H2O)/h, and heating rate from 0.1–8.0 °C/min. In consequence, RIAF varied from 1.3 to 2.8 with decreasing bed depth from 30 to 5 mm (plot not shown). The optimal bed depth was shown to be about 5−8 mm. The decrease in activity with increasing bed depth was attributed to an increase in water vapor and NOx concentration, which probably caused sintering of the Co oxide. The authors also postulated the formation of a CoOOH intermediate from TPR data, for a partially dried sample calcined at low concentrations of water and NOx as the result of a high flowrate and low heating rate, which may decompose to smaller Co3O4 NCs and after reduction smaller Co NCs. It was demonstrated that an air space velocity exceeding 1.0 Nm3 air/(kg Co(NO3)2·6 H2O)/h (equivalent to 1.1 Nm3 air/kgcat-h, 16.7 L/kgcat-min, or about 1000 h−1 for the catalysts of this study) and a heating rate below 1 °C/min are preferred conditions for maximizing catalyst activity. While the combination of high flow rate and low heating rate during calcination ensures rapid removal of water and NOx, improving Co oxide dispersion, it does not necessarily improve spatial and NC size distributions. In a 2013 review, van de Loosdrecht et al. [5] emphasized the importance of limiting the mobility of the Co nitrate intermediate on improving the spatial distribution by either addition (i) of NO or (ii) of a hydrocarbon during impregnation to enable a rapid overall exothermic decomposition of the intermediate. In addition, other methods may be used to improve spatial and size distributions, such as addition of carbon to the support or formation of immobile metal hydroxynitrates or Co nitrosyls prior to decomposition, as discussed in the previous section. Breejen et al.  [133] compared catalyst characteristics such as size, size distribution and the extent of reduction along with FT performance of Co/SiO2 catalysts when (i) calcined in air referred to as AC and (ii) when calcined in 1 vol% NO in He referred to as NC. Their results indicated higher dispersions (about 3-fold) and more homogeneoeus distribution of nanocrystals over the support surface for NC catalysts compared to AC catalysts. FT activity for the NC catalyst was also about two times higher compared to the AC catalyst. Similar results were obtained by Sietsma et al. [134]. The degree of reduction for NC after a reduction treatment at 450 °C was 77 % (compared to 96 % for AC) and was increased to 88 percent after 2  h of FT reaction. This observation suggests formation of small CoO nanocrystals in the NC catalyst followed by reduction in during reaction [19]. The effects of heating rate and gas flowrate during calcination were reported in a review by van de Loosdrecht et al. [5]. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images in Fig. 22 demonstrate how cobalt spatial distributions of a 23.1 % CoAl2O3, the same as the catalyst used in the previously-discussed study of van de Loosdrecht et al. [132], change when different calcination conditions are employed: (i) surprisingly, when the calcination is conducted at a heating rate of 1 °C/min and a flowrate of 1.0 Nm3 air/(kg Co(NO3)2·6 H2O)/h (equivalent to 1.1 Nm3 air/kgcat-h) which are close to the conditions recommended by Loosedrecht et al. [132] clustering occurs and large NCs of about 50 nm are formed (see Fig. 22a); (ii) Fig. 22b shows well-dispersed and uniformly-spatially-distributed oxide NCs obtained using “optimized heating rate and air space velocity to ensure optimum calcination;” (iii) Fig. 22c reveals well-dispersed, uniformly-distributed oxide NCs calcined at the same conditions as (i), but supported on carbon-coated alumina; and (iv) in Fig. 22d, a combination of well-dispersed, uniformly-distributed oxide NCs and significant clustering along with formation of large 50−100 nm NCs are evident after calcination in 1 mol% NO at the same flow and heating-rate conditions as in (i). It is unclear to what “optimum calcination” conditions relating to Fig. 23 b refers. We speculate it may refer to a much higher space velocity such as 1,500−2,000 h−1 and a much lower heating rate, e.g., 0.5 °C/min, in a region of temperature for which decomposition of nitrates occurs. Borg et al. [135] conducted a study of the effects of calcination atmosphere, final temperature, and flowrate on Co3O4 NC size, N-content, Co dispersion, and activity of 20 wt% Co/γ-Al2O3. A common precursor catalyst was prepared by incipient wetness with an aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, dried at 110 °C for 3 h, and divided into 1.2 g samples, which were calcined at a different final temperature ranging from 200 to 450 °C for 10 h in one of three atmospheres, i.e., air, a 50 % steam in air, or N2. During calcination, the temperature was ramped from 25 °C to Tfinal in 2 h (heating rates ranged from 2 to 3 °C/min). Catalysts were subsequently reduced in flowing H2 at 350 °C for 17 h. H2 uptake was measured at 40 °C; however, the extent (degree) of reduction (EOR or DOR) was not measured: rather in calculating dispersion, it was assumed that cobalt was completely reduced to the metal. Co nitrate is the favored starting material in the commercial preparation of Co catalysts because it is easily manufactured at low cost. However, it is essential that the residual nitrate content be removed during calcination to less than 0.1 %, since NOx scrubbing equipment is generally installed at the outlet of calciners for meeting NOx emissions standards, whereas NOx emissions during reduction cannot be tolerated, as scrubbing equipment is absent in catalyst reduction equipment [136]. Two previous studies have addressed the removal of catalyst nitrogen content to desired levels [135,136]. N-content (wt%) is plotted versus calcination temperature in Fig. 23a for different atmospheres and flow rates. The N-content of calcined samples is shown to vary from 0.7 to 1.2 wt% for samples calcined at 200 °C (473 K), while a decrease to a range of 0.1 to 0.2 wt% with increasing calcination temperature to 450 °C (723 K) is observed; the sample calcined in N2 reaches a minimum of 0.1 wt% at 350 °C (623 K), which is a N-content sufficiently low to prevent problems during reduction. In the case of samples calcined in air, increasing flow rate from 30 to 50 Nml/min decreases residual nitrate. Thus, calcination in N2 at 350−400 °C and a higher flow rate (50 vs 30 Nml/min/1.2 g) is shown to lower N-content of 20 wt% Co/γ-Al2O3 to safe levels (<0.1 wt%) for reduction. In TPR profiles shown in Fig. 23b, three peaks are present. The first peak is attributed to decomposition of nitrate precursor and second and the third peak represent reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co respectively. Presence of the third peak at very high temperature ranges, i.e., above 600 °C, strongly suggests formation of hard to reduce Co-support compunds in all catalysts of this study. Nevertheless, it is evident that with increasing the final calcination temperature from 200 °C (473 K) to 400 °C (673 K), for catalysts 1–7, peak associated with Co nitrate decomposition gets smaller until becomes negligible for A7/C7/D7 catalysts. Another interesting finding from Fig. 23b is that nitrate content in the N2 calcined catalyst is less than the air calcined catalyst. Casci and Antonini [136] claim a mild two-step method for removing nitrate species in a Co catalyst precursor to less than 0.1 wt%, without losing Co0 surface area, consisting of (i) calcining the Co nitrate impregnated support to a relatively low temperature of choice to partially remove nitrogen; and (ii) then heating the calcined catalyst precursor from room temperature to 200 °C in the presence of flowing 5% H2 in inert gas over 1.5 h, followed by a hold at Tfinal for 2−3 h. Their recommended space velocity was 100−500 h−1 NTP. At these conditions essentially no reduction of Co oxide occurs. If reduction were to occur, it would create handling problems (i.e., rapid oxidation in air with the tendency to combust) for the calcined precursor. 3.2.3 Preferred methods, precautions and recommendations for calcination Two safety precautions for calcining are (i) the concentration of hydrocarbon viscosity agents mentioned previously in connection with drying to ensure an ideal spatial distribution, and oxidizer concentration in solution combustion synthesis must be carefully optimized, since if the organic concentration is too high, calcination in air or N2 could initiate a very high temperature combustion reaction with Co nitrate and (ii) whether in the laboratory or plant, provision must be made to scrub NOx, which otherwise is a serious safety, environmental, and corrosion hazard. The choice of calcination temperature is important to the design of a stable catalyst. The conventional wisdom has been to choose a low temperature to facilitate preparation of a well-dispersed catalyst. However, there are at least two reasons for choosing a moderately-high calcination temperature. First, for cobalt and perhaps nickel catalysts prepared from the nitrate, it is necessary, as previously explained, to remove catalyst nitrate content during calcination to 0.1 % or less before reduction in a separate apparatus. As discussed previously, Borg et al. [135] showed that moderately-high calcination temperatures (i.e., 350−400 °C) are required for this purpose. In addition, low heating rates and high flow rates are critical as recommended by van de Loosdrecht et al. [132] An alternative for removing nitrates is the patented low temperature method of Casci and Antonini; [136] however, commercial practice of this method would require paying royalties. Second, a moderately high calcination temperature will, based on previous examples, produce larger Co3O4 NCs that during reduction produce larger Co0 NCs, more resistant to sintering. Belambe et al. [137] reported decreasing Co surface area with increasing calcination temperature for CoRu/γ-Al2O3 which indicates that larger oxide NCs were formed with increasing calcination temperature. Formation of surface Co aluminates or other surface Co support compounds in fractions greater than 8−10% of the total cobalt in a catalyst should be avoided during calcination, since it causes loss of expensive cobalt and compromises catalyst performance. While the data of Borg et al. [135] for calcined catalysts provide new insights into effects of calcination temperature and atmosphere on N-content, their NC size and dispersion data for Co3O4 and Co0 in calcined and reduced catalysts respectively, must be questioned because of (i) their lack of EOR (DOR) data and (ii) the extensive formation of surface Co aluminates, evident in the broad peaks in their TPR pattern at 500−800 °C. Fig. 23b reveals peak maxima at about 600 °C (873 K) for catalysts A2, A3, A4, A6, and A7 calcined at 523, 548, 573, 623, and 673 K, indicating that these catalysts would have to be reduced above 600 °C to achieve nearly complete reduction to Co0; instead, these catalysts were reduced at 350 °C and hence all 5 catalysts were probably less than 50–60 % reduced based on TPR areas. The TPR results are typical of those in many other papers (too many to cite) in which substantial fractions of Co support compounds (30–60 % of available cobalt) were formed during calcination of Co precursors on unstabilized γ-Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 supports. Formation of surface Co support compounds in these studies is inherent in the strong interaction of Co2+ with unstabilized supports, e.g., [138,139] and probably further caused by calcination at low flow rates, high heating rates, and high temperature, the last of which probably facilitates Co2+ cation diffusion into vacancies of the γ-Al2O3 spinel, while the former two conditions likely generate high concentrations of water and nitric acid which in turn hydrate the support surface. This could be followed by the strong interaction of Co oxides with the hydrated support surface to form a surface Co-support compound, e.g., CoO Al2O3 [139]. An earlier fundamental study provides further insights into the formation of surface Co aluminates during calcination [139]. Chin and Hercules [139] employed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, low-energy ion scattering spectrsocopy, and secondary ion mass spectrometery to the study of the strong interaction of Co oxides with γ-Al2O3 during calcination. This interaction apparently stems from migration of Co2+ into unoccupied tetrahedral (Co-t) and octahedral (Co-o) lattice sites of the cation-deficient spinel structure of γ-Al2O3 in the top 2−3 surface layers during calcination. The relative distribution of Co3O4 NCs, Co-t, and Co-o species is influenced by both Co metal loading and calcination temperature. Thus, diffusion of Co2+ into Co-t sites, favored at low Co loadings (wt% Co < 5 %) and high calcination temperatures (Tcalcn > 400 °C), yields a surface CoAl2O4 spinel which is irreducible at typical reduction conditions. Occupation of Co-o sites is favored by high Co loadings (wt% Co > 5 %) and low calcination temperatures (Tcalcn ≤ 400 °C); Co-o sites are reducible at typical reduction conditions. Moreover, as metal loading increases and Co-o sites are completely filled, phase segregation to bulk-like Co3O4 NCs is observed. Belambe et al. [137] studied the effects of calcination temperature from 250 to 400 °C on reducibility of 20 wt% Co/0.5 wt% Ru/Al2O3, finding that percent reduction decreased from 77 to 59 % with increasing calcination temperature. Building upon the work of Chin and Hercules [139], we hypothesize that 3−5 wt% oxides of La, Si, or Ba when added to γ-Al2O3 will occupy Co-t sites thereby preventing surface CoAl2O4 formation. However, formation of less than about 3–7 % of cobalt as cobalt surface aluminates on alumina-supported catalyst during commercially-relevant operation may be unavoidable [11,17]. While Co-support compounds probably increase Co0 adhesion to the support, thereby inhibiting sintering [15], other less expensive oxides in small amounts can be added to alumina, silica, or titania for the same purpose [1]. We submit that Co catalysts in previous studies, in which cobalt-support spinels were formed, could have been greatly improved by (i) using an Al2O3 support stabilized with 3−5% of another oxide, e.g., SiO2, ZrO2, or BaO [1]; (ii) preheating the support to a high temperature (900–1100 °C) to remove water and hydroxyl groups and to further stabilize the support prior to impregnation; and (iii) adding a noble metal reduction promoter [106,107]. Two examples, of TPRs in which the peaks for reduction of Co3O4 and CoO occur at acceptably low temperature and little or no surface Co aluminate (at 500−800 °C) is observed, are shown in Fig. 24 for (a) 20 %Co/0.5 %Ru/Al2O3 calcined at 300 °C [140] and (b) 25 %Co/0.5 %Pt/Al2O3 calcined at 250 °C [106]. The authors apparently conducted their preparations and calcinations at near ideal conditions to avoid formation of cobalt aluminate. 3.3 Reduction The need to reduce Co catalysts at high gas rates to ensure low water partial pressures and high activity was first recognized by German scientists during the 1930′s [141]. In 1976, Bartholomew and Farrauto [142] reported that a space velocity above 2000 h−1 was necessary to prepare high surface area Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. Although previous investigators may have used TPRs to design reduction heating schedules, no papers or patents to our knowledge have reported such details; however, it has been practiced in the BYU catalysis lab for over 3 decades. Several papers and patents specify heating rates, constant temperature holds, high H2 flowrates, and increasing H2 concentration near the end of the procedure, all for purposes of sustaining low rates of reduction and low PH2O. Examples are furnished below. US Patent 4,399,234 [143] discloses that following drying and calcination of Co catalysts, reduction is conducted slowly overnight, using a mixture of H2 in N2 to maintain a slow reduction rate; for example, at the beginning of the reduction, 5 mol% H2/N2 is used. H2 concentration can be slowly increased while maintaining a constant reduction rate. A reduction heating schedule is also suggested: (1) heating at 5 °C/min to 100 °C and holding temperature constant at 100 °C for 1 h, (2) increasing temperature at 0.5 °C/min to 200 °C and holding for 0.5−16 h; and (3) heating at 1 °C/min to 350 °C and holding temperature constant for several hours. After the last impregnation step, the catalyst is reduced slowly (without drying and calcination) using a similar heating schedule. In US Patent 4,585,798 [144], a similar heating schedule is recommended, involving 2 consecutive steps: (1) heating at a rate of 0.5−1 °C/min to a maximum hold temperature of 200−250 °C and holding for 16−24 h and (2) heating at a rate of 0.5−1 °C/min to a maximum hold temperature of 350−400 °C and holding for 16−24 h. It was suggested that the reduction be conducted sufficiently slowly with sufficiently high flowrate to maintain PH2O below 1%. US Patent 4,717,702 [145] claims the same 2-step heating process during reduction as in 4,585,798 [144]. Three US patents from Exxon and two from Shell disclose preferred values of reduction temperature, flowrate and minimum PH2O in the exit gas as follows: (i) in 4,738,948 [146] and 4,822,824 [147], reduction of Co/Zr/TiO2 in H2 at 400 °C and a SV of 2000 h−1; (ii) in 5,021,387 [148], reduction of a calcined Co/Zr/SiO2 catalyst at 260 °C, 3 bar, and a SV of 6000 h−1; (iii) in 5,036,032 [149], direct reduction of a dried Co/SiO2 (prepared by melt impregnation) at 0.2 °C/min to 350 °C, after which the catalyst is melt-impregnated again, rereduced, giving a dispersion (D) of 7.3 %; (iv) in 5,073,661 [150], a Co/Zr/SiO2 catalyst may be reduced with H2 or H2-containing gas at 250−300 °C, but catalyst performance is improved if PH2 is increased gradually or stepwise from 1−100% to satisfy the relation (PH2)final = 5 × (PH2) initial. US Patents 5,168,091 [151] and 5,258,411 [152] disclose reduction conditions for 7 wt% Co/0.6 wt% Re/Al2O3-TiO2 and 13 wt% Co/1.2 wt% Re/Al2O3-TiO2 involving ranges of temperature (250−450 °C), pressure (1−10 atm), and SV (300−15,000 h−1), and heating rate (all above 10 °C/min). While the reported productivities are low, methane selectivities are 3−5%. Behrmann et al. [153] have also addressed optimal conditions for reduction. Loosdrecht et al. [5] showed the impact of the water partial pressure during reduction of a 30 g Co/0.075 gPt/100 g alumina catalyst on the starting FTS performance, indicating that a PH2O of less than 30 mbar should be targeted for maximum activity. A secondary reduction process involving an additional calcination of a prereduced and passivated Co catalyst at 300–350 °C followed by rereduction at 300–350 °C (overall treatment is reduction, oxidation, reduction or ROR) has been found to increase its activity and dispersion [44,144,154–164]. Kobylinski et al. [154] reported that the ROR treatment is effective in improving promoted and unpromoted Co and Ni catalyst supported on Al2O3 or SiO2, although γ- or η-Al2O3 is preferred; up to a factor of two increases in activity are reported. After ROR treatment at 300 °C of 12 wt% Co/0.3 wt% Ru/MgCr2O4 reduced before and after at 500 °C, Co dispersion increases from 3.8 to 7.2 %. Thus, the major benefit appears to be a redispersion of Co which includes spreading of a CoO film on the support during oxidation followed by breaking up of the film during rereduction to produce small crystallites of metal. However, the ROR-treated catalyst containing clusters of small Co NCs is highly susceptible to sintering. A similar treatment, i.e., application of high-temperature oxidation at 300−400 °C of a previously-reduced-spent-catalyst followed by rereduction has been studied and proposed as a regeneration method for redispersion of a sintered Co catalyst [155–164]. However, this method also produces clusters of small to medium-large Co NCs, depending upon the conditions of ROR (see Fig. 25 ). Small NCs of dCo less than about 6 nm will undergo sintering by OR, while NCs larger than about 8 nm will, because of their spatial proximity, readily undergo sintering by CMC. Thus, typical regeneration via oxidation of a reduced spent catalyst followed by reduction is also likely to produce catalysts prone to sintering due to clustering and spatial proximity of NCs (see Fig. 25) [11,160]. Since these methods produce catalysts highly susceptible to sintering, further research is required to improve spatial distribution during regeneration. Several papers [29,165–170] have focused on a scientific understanding of the reduction process for supported Co using XRD, TPR, XPS, and EXAFS, including (i) formation of surface-cobalt-aluminate during reduction [138,170–173]; (ii) evidence that reduction of cobalt precursors proceeds via a conversion of Co3O4 to CoO to Co metal (see Eqs. (5) and (6)); [23,29,106,166,171–175] (iii) determination of coordination numbers of Co in each of these three phases; [174] (iv) reaction kinetics of Co/Al2O3 reduction; [29,166] and (v) evidence that Co is metallic under typical FTS conditions [23,174–176]. (5) Co3O4 + H2 → 3CoO + H2O (6) CoO + H2 → Co + H2O Zhang et al. [171], Jongsomjit et al. [173] and Sirijaruphan et al. [172] studied effects of reduction in 0–3 % H2O/H2 (at a space velocity of 16,000 h−1) to 350 °C of 20 wt% Co/γ-Al2O3 and/or 20 wt% Co/0.5 wt% Ru/γ-Al2O3 on formation of a surface-Co-aluminate. As the water addition rate was increased the temperature of the second peak corresponding to Eq. (6) was shifted from 500 to 700 °C and a smaller fraction of CoO was reducible; thus, addition of water vapor during reduction causes increased formation of surface-Co-aluminate [171]. Addition of Ru causes a shift in TPR peaks to lower temperatures, increased reducibility, and less Co surface aluminate formation [171]. Surface Co aluminate formation during reduction of Co/γ-Al2O3 is facilitated by the interaction of well-dispersed CoO, either formed by Eq. (5) or reoxidation of small Co0 NCs during H2 reduction by product water vapor or added water vapor [172]. ZrO2 addition to Co/SiO2 has been reported to stabilize this catalyst for commercial FTS [5]. Jongsomjit et al. [173] reported that addition of ZrO2 to γ-Al2O3 stabilized Co/γ-Al2O3 against formation of surface Co aluminate during calcination and reduction, probably by migration of Zr2+ cations into the tetrahedral sites of γ-Al2O3 instead of Co; ZrO2 promotion was also found to enhance reduction and mass-based activity of Co/γ-Al2O3 for FTS. Using XRD, TPR, XPS, and EXAFS, Ernst et al. [174] established that reduction in H2 of a calcined cobalt catalyst precursor proceeds via conversion of Co3O4 to CoO to Co0; moreover, they determined the coordination number of Co in each of these phases and demonstrated that Co0 is the active phase in FTS. Jacobs et al. [175] have reviewed applications of synchrotron and other spectrscopic methods (e.g., EXAFS/XANES, XRD, XPS, Raman, and STXM) in investigations of (i) the chemistry of Co catalyst reduction, (ii) the local atomic structure of Co reduction promoters in contact with Co0 in supported Co catalysts and their effects on activity and selectivity; and (iii) effects of NC size on oxidation of small Co0 NCs and sintering of larger NCs by CMC. Fig. 26 compares EXAFS-TPR spectra for reduction in H2 of (a) 15 wt% Co/Al2O3; (b) 15 wt% Co/0.5 wt% Pt/γ-Al2O3; with (c) H2 TPR profiles for 15 wt% and 25 wt% Co/Al2O3 unpromoted and promoted with 0.5 wt% Pt. In the EXAFS-TPR spectra (Fig. 26a and b) magnitudes of the Fourier-transforms are plotted versus temperature and interatomic distances, i.e., Co-O and Co-Co in Co3O4 and CoO and Co-Co in Co0; thereby, the three phases are identified by their local atomic structure. Temperatures of transitions between the three phases can be approximately determined from these two figures; as expected, transitions between the different phases are shifted to lower temperatures for the Pt promoted 15 % Co catalyst. Very significant peak shifts to lower temperatures for promoted 15 % and 25 % Co catalysts relative to unpromoted catalysts are shown quantitatively in the TPR patterns in Fig. 26c, i.e., 194 and 120 °C for peaks 1 and 2 for 25 wt% Co and 138 and 120 °C for 15 wt% Co, demonstrating the high efficiency of Pt to promote reduction of both Co3O4 and CoO consistent with results of Cook et al. [106] Also evident in the TPR patterns for the unpromoted catalysts is a second peak at 600 °C, extending to 750 °C, which is indicative of substantial formation of a surface CoAl2O4. No mention was made by the authors regarding Co aluminate in connection with these results. As in many studies of reduction, e.g., the examples in the review of Jacobs et al. [175] the objective was to maximize Co dispersion (while avoiding dCo < 6 nm to avoid Co0 oxidation) and catalytic activity; moreover, a typical reduction temperature was 350 °C. We emphasize the wisdom in employing higher reduction temperatures (i.e., 400−500 °C) for promoted Co catalysts to avoid formation of small Co NCs (i.e. 3−6 nm) that are either easily oxidized and form Co support compounds and/or are sintered during FTS. In addition, we emphasize, again, the wisdom of adding a support stabilizer (e.g., 2−5 wt% SiO2, La2O3, TiO2, or ZrO2) to Al2O3 and other supports to avoid formation of Co aluminate. Indeed, the previously-mentioned work of Keyvanloo et al. [17] demonstrates that a precisely-designed reduction of 25 wt% Co/0.25 wt% Pt/5 wt% SiO2-Al2O3 to 450 °C to prepare an average dCo of 11 nm prevented formation of Co aluminates and sintering over 33 day FT runs, the time-frame over which sintering of NCs smaller than 10−11 nm have been observed [11,177,178]. Tsakoumis et al. [138] studied reoxidation thresholds for a highly dispersed 20 wt% Co/0.5 wt% Re/γ-Al2O3 using syncrotron XAS and XANES to determine Co0 and Co2+ concentrations before, during and after reaction. The catalyst was reduced in H2 at a space velocity of about 500 h−1 and a heating rate of 3 °C/min to 300 °C and held there for 4 h. In view of the low space velocity, high heating rate, and low reduction temperature resulting in an average dCo of 6.2 nm, significant formation of a surface Co aluminate during reduction would be expected (as was observed in TPR peaks at 600 °C in Fig. 23b for a similar Co/γ-Al2O3 catalysts following reduction). However, it was determined from XANES data (Fig. 27 a) that 91 % of the cobalt was reduced to Co0 and that 9% CoO was present, while no Co aluminate was predicted (see Fig. 27b). After 32 h of FT reaction, the Co0 concentration had decreased from 92 % to about 80 %, while that of CoO had increased slightly from 9 to about 10 % and about 9% CoAl2O4 formed according to the XANES data (see Fig. 27a). The schematic in Fig. 27b represents the reduced surface; it comprises two hemispherical Co0 crystallites (one having a diameter smaller and one larger than 5.3 m) attached to a planar γ-Al2O3 surface by 1−2 layers Co2+ (presumably CoO) and a monolayer patch of Co2+ presumably representing small, unreduced CoO strongly held to the Al2O3 surface. Perhaps, these small, strongly-held CoO NCs that are not reducible at 400 °C as depicted in Fig. 27b constitute one form of a surface Co aluminate. Fig. 27c depicts that during 32 h of reaction, the smaller Co0 NC has undergone oxidation, spreading over the surface and in the presence of water vapor has interacted with the hydrated alumina surface to form a 1−2 monolayer solid CoAl2O4 which could be a second, more stable form of Co aluminate. The apparent lack of reduction of small CoO NCs and the decrease in concentration of Co0 shown in Fig. 27a is surprising, in view of the compelling XANES evidence by Saib et al. [178] that CoO content decreases from 47 to 20 %, while Co0 increases from 53 to 80 % during the first 48 h of FT reaction for a 20 wt% Co/0.05 wt% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst having an average dCo of 6 nm. Saib et al. [178] noted that it is difficult to differentiate between CoO and Co aluminate using XANES. The differences may be due to a greater number of oxidizable Co NCs with a surface averaged dCo of 5.2 nm [138]. Jalama et al. [179] reported that reduction of Co/TiO2 in syngas (H2/CO = 2) produces a more highly-reduced, active, stable, and selective catalyst compared to that reduced in H2. Jongsomjit et al. [180] found that addition of 3–5 vol% CO during H2 reduction of Co catalysts apparently mitigates deleterious effects of water vapor during reduction, resulting in active catalysts of higher Co reducibility and dispersion relative to those reduced in dilute water vapor in H2. These observations of higher reducibility in syngas are consistent with the previous discussion of CoO reduction by CO [167,168,179,181], which occurs either during rapid reduction of the unreduced catalyst in syngas or at a relatively moderate rate for a partially-reduced catalyst over the first 10 days of FT reaction and more slowly during reaction over 50–100 days as determined by XAFS/XANES [176]. Activation of 10 wt% Co/SiO2 in H2, CO, or H2/CO was studied by de la Pena O’Shea et al. [181] using SEM, TEM, XPS, XRD, and in situ DRIFT-MS from 25 to 500 °C. H2/CO activation produced redispersion and high performance in FTS. Patanou et al. [182] and Tsakoumis et al. [183] examined the effects of sequential H2/CO/H2 activation treatment at different temperatures on the structure and FTS performance of 20 %Co/0.5 %Re/γ-Al2O3 using H2 chemisorption, TPR, Raman spectroscopy, XAS and XANES. A standard reduction was performed for all samples by heating them in H2 at 1 °C/min to 350 °C with a hold for 10 h, followed by carburization in 14 bar CO at different temperatures. The optimal carburization temperature was found to be 230 °C. A second reduction was conducted at temperatures from 200−450 °C in 50 °C increments to decompose the carbide. The optimal temperature in terms of high activity and C5+ selectivity, is 350 °C, which is illustrated in Fig. 28 ; treatment at this temperature removes all lattice carbon to produce hcp NCs with a minimum number of defects. It was concluded that maximum activity and C5+ selectivity is associated with the defect-free hcp NCs of Co, produced by decomposition of the carbide. These results are much better than those produced by a standard reduction in H2 to produce fcc Co NCs. The crucial question regarding these results in the perspective of this review is which phase, fcc or hcp, will be more stable during FT reaction, a question that was not addressed in either paper [182,183]. Janse van Rensburg et al. [184] predicted that the Co hcp phase is less stable towards sintering via Ostwald ripening if dCo is below 110 nm based on surface energy data from Kitakami et al. [185]; Kitakami et al. [185] mentioned that Co NCs smaller than 20 nm are pure fcc Co, although the bulk SE is larger for Co fcc compared with Co hcp by about 10 % [186]. Clearly, additional surface energy data and FT runs with fcc and hcp catalysts over 30+ days are needed to resolve this issue. Additional recent studies of the relative stability towards sintering of hcp vs fcc Co is discussed in our companion review [19]. van de Loosdrecht et al. [5] have addressed the thermodynamics of reduction reactions (see Eqs. (5) and (6)). Several groups have studied conversion kinetics during reduction using quantitative TPR [23,176,187,188]. TPR patterns in Fig. 29 [176] are shown for a spherical Co/SiO2 model catalyst having average NC diameters of 4, 13, and 28 nm. Peaks for the Co-4 nm catalyst are shifted to high temperatures of 297 and 542 °C, while those for Co-13 nm and Co-28 nm are shifted to progressively lower temperatures (200 and 326 °C for Co-13 nm and 166 and 287 °C for Co-28 nm) indicating higher rates of reduction for larger NCs. Ratios of Peak 2/Peak 1 areas are 8.5, 2.9, and 2.8 for Co-4 nm, Co-13 nm, and Co-28 nm, respectively. Thus, the peak ratios for the catalysts of large diameter (Co-13 nm and Co-28 nm) are within experimental error, the same as the predicted ratio of 3.0 based on the stoichiometries of Eqs. (5) and (6). The large Peak 2 and large ratio of Peak 2/Peak 1 of 8.5 for Co-4 nm are consistent with formation of a surface Co aluminate above 540 °C or alternatively small, strongly adsorbed CoO NCs, which are equally poorly reducible. In a study of reduction kinetics of Co3O4 [189] reduction profiles were obtained using thermogravimetry at several constant heating rates for a sample calcined at 400 °C in (i) pure H2 and (ii) in 25 % H2 + Ar. From a Kissinger plot (see Fig. 30 ), activation energies for Co3O4 reduction were calculated to be ∼86 kJ mol−1. The rate data were fit using the expanded Prout–Tompkins model, shown in Eq. (7); (7) dα/dt = k(1−α)n (1−q(1−α))m where α is the extent of conversion of the reacting phase, q is a constant, and n and m are adjustable parameters to achieve the best fit to the experimental data. The coefficient q, which is slightly less than one, models a nonzero rate. This model is applicable to a wide range of solid-state processes involving nucleation and growth. Recent, representative studies [29,138,165,166,175] employed sophisticated, state-of-the-art synchrotron- spectroscopic and microscopic tools including XAS, EXAFS, XANES, ASAXS, HRTEM, HAADF-STEM, μ-XRD-CT, etc. to determine nanophase chemistry, dispersion, spatial distribution of NCs, and Co0 NC morphology in cobalt catalysts, during calcination, reduction, and reaction. Unfortunately, these researchers neglected to give necessary attention to one or more of the following critical, basic aspects of preparation and characterization, i.e., failing to: (i) stabilize γ-Al2O3 and other supports with other oxides to prevent formation of Co-support compounds such as Co aluminate during calcination and/or reduction; (ii) use TPR to verify if Co aluminates were formed during calcination and/or reduction; (iii) conduct preparation, drying, calcination, and reduction procedures under precisely controlled conditions as described in the present and previous sections to prevent formation of Co NCs smaller than 5 nm in diameter or of clusters of Co NCs larger than 50−100 nm in diameter; (iv) use H2 chemisorption to verify XPS or XANES measurements of dispersion; and (v) choose a small catalyst particle size to avoid water buildup and oxidation inside the catalyst during reduction. Thus, what might have been breakthrough studies, fell seriously short due to that lack of attention to fundamentals discussed in the present section. 3.3.1 Preferred methods, precautions and recommendations Reduction is a critical step in preparation of an active metallic catalyst. If the reduction step is not designed and performed carefully it can negatively affect the NC size, size and spatial distributions, and Co phase. Performing a temperature programmed reduction (TPR) at 1 °C/min is a critical step prior to reduction. The TPR profile is analogous to a roadmap for a successful reduction in terms of optimal heating rate and constant temperature holds as a function of reduction temperature. The underlying principle is to maintain a low reduction rate and low PH2O. In general following considerations should be followed for a successful reduction: (i) slow reduction rate, low heating rates (0.5−1.0 °C/min) and temperature holds of 0.5–2 h at the beginning of each TPR peak; (ii) high space velocities (greater than 2000 h−1); and (iii) varying H2/N2 concentration from 1−100 % and pressures from 1−3 bar, stepwise through the reduction process. PH2O should be limited to less than 1% or less than 0.1 mbar of H2O. 4 Conclusions 4.1 Design of sintering resistant catalysts Properties of catalysts affecting sintering resistance are highly reliant on choices of support, promoters, and precise catalyst synthesis methods, including choices of metal precusor, method of precursor deposition on the support, solvent, and methods of drying, calcination, and reduction. Catalyst properties that determine sintering rate include NC size, NC spatial and size distributions, pore size and pore size distribution, support properties, and metal-support bonding (Eadh). A typical commercial catalyst may contain 20 wt% Co/0.05−0.5 wt% NM/1−10 wt% MOx/support where NM is a noble metal promoter consisting of Pt, Re, or Ru; MOx is a metal oxide-support stabilizer; and support is typically Al2O3, SiO2, or TiO2. Properties of an optimized Co FT catalyst resistant to sintering include a stabilized support and a dpore of 15 nm, a well-reduced catalyst containing NCs of dCo = 10−12 nm distributed uniformly inside support pores. 4.2 Design of optimal support/promoter properties Support chemical and physical properties to minimize sintering include in part (a) optimally strong support-metal bonding, i.e. high Eadh, and (b) NC size, size distribution, NC spatial distribution. Important support physical properties that affect sintering rate include surface area, pore volume, porosity, average pore size, and pore size distribution. Support chemical properties include chemical structure, composition, high purity, OH adsorption capacity, and hydrothermal stability. Optimal support properties for high performance commercial Co FT catalysts include the following : (a) physical properties: SA = 50−150 m2/g, dpore = 12–16 nm, Vpore = 0.5−0.6 cm3/g, and porosity < 0.5 and (b) chemical properties: (i) a support free of catalyst poisons, e.g., containing < 25 ppm of Na and S (ii) addition of 1−10% of a stabilizer consisting of an oxide of Al, La, Si, Ti, and Zr to Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 to prevent formation of aluminates, silicates, or titanates (iii) BaO to reduce acid site concentration of the support; (iv) 5−10 % carbon on the support surface to improve size, and spatial distributions; and (v) support functional groups which can trap metal adatoms or hinder NCs diffusing over the surface. Co promoters to minimize sintering by facilitating reduction of cobalt to Co0 at lower temperatures include mainly noble metals, most especially Pt, Re, Ru; a higher extent of reduction (EOR) is also associated with higher activity and selectivity to C5+. 4.3 Design of an optimal catalyst preparation method for sintering resistance (a) Preparation by impregnation. Most commercial Co FT catalysts are prepared by wet (less preferably dry) impregnation due to its (i) simplicity, rapidity, capability for depositing stepwise the precursor at moderately-high loadings (e.g., 10 % for Co nitrate impregnation in the mesopores of an oxidic support), and (ii) the high likelihood of distributing the impregnating liquid with solution phase Co2+ uniformly along pores and through the catalyst particle. Disadvantages of impregnation are: (i) non-uniform distribution of the catalyst precursor e.g., Co nitrate; and (ii) the necessity of repeating the impregnation, drying and calcination, for Co nitrate impregnation 2−3 times to obtain a Co loading of 20−30%. (b) Deposition precipitation (DP); advantages of DP include: (i) a favorable one-step route to achieving high loadings, i.e., 20–50 wt % and high Co dispersions; and (ii) when properly conducted, DP favors uniform distribution of the active precursor inside support pores. Disadvantages of conventional DP include: (i) the tendency to form small NCs (e.g. 3−5 nm) which are reduced only at high temperatures in H2 and (ii) these small Co NCs apparently undergo rapid sintering via OR during FT reaction. A new, promising one-pot solvent-deficient precipitation (SDP) has been developed which produces Co catalysts that are easily reduced and having activity selectivity properties comparable to those prepared by impregnation [35]. (c). Solution combustion synthesis (SCS) [96,102–105]. The Oxford catalyst (40–45 % Co/ 12–18 % ZrO2/ SiO2 is very active, selective, and highly resistant to sintering, with an apparent moderately-strong Co-ZrO2 interaction (a moderately-high Eadh) and a uniform spatial distribution of Co NCs. The key to this development is precise control of the combustion step by using (i) relatively low concentrations of Co nitrate and an organic fuel and (ii) precise temperature programmed drying and calcination to a low temperature of 250 °C. One important drawback of this method is that up to 5–6 repetitions of the combustion, drying, and calcination are required to achieve desirably high Co loadings of up to 45 %. 4.4 Design of optimal pretreatment steps to produce sintering-resistant catalysts Consider this perspective. All that has been accomplished in an optimized preparation can be undone by a single careless pretreatment step. 4.4.1 Drying To avoid sintering, drying should produce a uniform metal-precursor concentration profile. Catalysts prepared by impregnation, precipitation, and SDP need carefully controlled drying to remove liquid or moisture from the impregnated solid. Drying of impregnated catalysts is generally carried out at temperatures ranging from 80 to 150 °C to remove the solvent. Drying is a three-step process consisting of preheating, drying at a constant rate, and completion during a falling rate period. The best results are obtained using a thin bed of catalyst (e.g., a fine-wire-mesh boat about 0.8–1.0 cm deep) or a well controlled fluidized bed in which the rate of moisture is uniformly removed over its entire surface by flowing air or N2 of adequate humidity to prevent rapid, non-uniform drying, either through or over the sample. During drying, metal precursor distribution can change significantly; the final catalyst profile is determined by the relative magnitude of the evaporation rate (a function of temperature and drying time), adsorption strength of the precursor to the support surface, capillary flow to the exterior support surface during the constant rate period, and dissolved precursor back-diffusion during the falling rate period. An acceptably uniform metal distribution is predicted and observed for an 10 wt% Co/Al2O3 dried at a temperature of 90 °C–110 °C. 4.4.2 Calcination Calcination is generally required only for catalysts prepared by impregnation. The purpose of calcination is to decompose the precursor (usually hydrated Co nitrate for Co catalysts) slowly due to the net exothermic process; this is accomplished through high flow rates of air or N2 and a low heating rate as follows: (i) TPN2 and TPO scans are used in the design of calcination processes that produce optimal catalyst dispersion and spatial distribution; for example, TPN2 or TPO of a 25 mg sample of dried, catalyst at a heating rate of 1 °C/min from 25−400 °C is designed to capture DTA and DSC curves providing precise location of decomposition peaks for design of calcination heating schedules, e.g., a heating rate of 1 °C /min in the temperature regimes for which no peak is observed, and 0.5 °C/min in the temperature regime(s) in which calcination peaks occur, with holds of 1 h before and after the first peak at about 160−170 °C, ensuring a mild, N2 or O2-assisted decomposition of the anhydrous Co nitrate to Co3O4; (ii) during calcination, it is critical to flow N2 or air at a space velocity (SV) of 1500 h−1-2000 h−1 (for a 23 wt% Co catalyst, SV being proportional to Co loading); and (iii) commercially, nitrates must be removed during calcination to less than 0.1 wt% by calcining to 350 °C to prevent corrosion of reduction equipment and to minimize NOx emissions. 4.4.3 Reduction The objectives for reduction of Co FT catalysts are to obtain: (i) an initial extent of reduction (EOR) of 80–90% which is associated with high activity for Co FTS; and (ii) an average dCo of 10−12 nm, a sharp NC size distribution, and a uniform NC spatial distribution (rather than clustering) to ensure stability against sintering for long periods of reaction, while at the same time sustaining moderately-high activity and C5+ selectivity. The method-based concepts important in Co catalyst reduction are: (i) slow reduction by use of low heating rates of 0.5–1 °C/min and temperature holds of 0.5–2 h just at the beginning of each TPR peak as determined from a TPR at 1 °C/min; (2) high space velocities (greater than 2,000–4,000 h−1);and (ii) varying H2/N2 concentration from 10 % and increasing gradually to 100 % at the maximum temperature and increasing pressure from 1 to 3 bar, at the maximum temperature. PH2O should be limited to less than 1% or less than 0.1 mbar. Consecutive reduction in H2/CO/H2 atmospheres has been used to produce catalyst containing mostly hcp-Co with higher activity and C5+ selectivity than conventional fcc-Co catalysts prepared by H2 reduction only. coredata.dc:description: Catalyst deactivation is of a major concern in industrial applications. Catalyst deactivation in any process can be minimized through: (i) appropriate catalyst design, and (ii) careful process control. In the present review we focus on the design of a Co catalyst to significantly hinder catalyst deactivation via sintering during FT reaction while enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity. First, it is shown how support and promoter physical and chemical properties can affect Co catalyst design. Support physical and chemical properties essential for preparing an optimally active, selective, and stable, commercial Co FT catalysts are recommended. Secondly, it is explained how carefully-controlled deposition of a Co salt via industrially-realistic methods is critical in controlling catalyst precursor-support interactions, nanocrystal size, and spatial distributions vital to sintering resistance. Three catalyst precursor deposition methods are discussed: impregnation, precipitation, and solution combustion; advantages and disadvantages of each method are detailed. Finally, effects of drying, calcination, and reduction on catalyst properties important to activity, selectivity and resistance to sintering are explained, and best practices for conducting each step are recommended.
coredata.dc:title: Optimizing preparations of Co Fischer-Tropsch catalysts for stability against sintering
